Why You Should Copy Anime:
https://i.imgur.com/zNDsyF0.jpg
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kbKqIJcIUCw
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dgjx6y6B_G8
Krenz Accuracy Imgs: https://files.catbox.moe/tklkj8.rar

**Strive for quantity AND quality.**

Anime Studying:
>Copy anime references exactly and draw them from memory. Use illustrations, screenshots, anime figures, 3D models, etc.
>Don’t copy recklessly. Use construction, color theory, and other fundamental concepts to rehearse a drawing process that you can later easily manipulate for original artwork.
>Post all of your anime studies. Post even when you’re told not to. Create an art community that actually draws and improves together instead of just talking about it.
>Number your attempts and link to your previous posts.
>Critiquers should lead by example by posting their studies.

General Anime Style Discussion:
>Questions about achieving certain styles/techniques/compositions etc.
>Drawing methods, study habits, resources, tutorials, tools, software, etc
>Be specific and try to post a sample of your study attempts before asking for help.

**Draw copies from good anime styled references to mindfully up our mileage, internalize appealing aesthetics, and learn from each other’s processes and knowledge.**

https://pastebin.com/Yz2scAEc

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6516603
The church wanted to control people, so desired art that depicted biblical events in realistic painting.
Asian art from the same period was more focused on telling folk tales and the stories of rulers, depicted in the same style as old historical art to enhance the mythos or whatever you'd call it. Plus the nature of woodblock printing which was a big thing in ancient Asia was more suited for simplistic and reproduceable depictions.
The west could've easily gone down the same path if instead of pivoting towards realism due to the church' they just kept doing the same old pre-renaissance paintings that came before them.
And also worthy of note is the notion of beauty that atleast Japan's case, which was a top priority when creating art for them, since realism was dirty and such.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Western art sucked for centuries, until they decided to gitgud.

The same would have eventually happened in Asia, it just so happens they had contact with the West before having the opportunity to come up with it themselves.

Same thing happens with bronze age and other important kingdom-forming technologies. Everyone was a bunch of apes shitting in the bushes, until some village figured out at random how to bend metal to its will.
In the grand scale of things, mankind did jackshit for millions of years, then struck up on this BIG discovery and completely changed in the span of 15.000 years.

Compared to the millions of years dillydallying, 15.000 years is not a lot, if we as a species only discovered this technology TODAY, the timeline of human evolution would look about the same. But because SOME people discovered it earlier than other, it gave them a huge advantage in conquering their neighbors and becoming king of the hill, forcing everyone else to sink or swim.

Because in west, there was a distinct class of craftspeople who branched out to artists - people making stone sculptures came from stonemasons, etc. If they wanted to make art, they needed to make art that would sell to the nobility or the merchant class.

In EA the people who did the art - at least the art that received any recognition - were the nobles who had done nothing but shitpost in scrolls for their entire lives. They didn't give a shit if it was any better than the bare necessary level to hang on their wall, because they could just tell people to collect more taxes for them.

TL;DR: West invented capitalism.

>>6514521
>No there's litterally no image data in the weights/parameters or model
Both images and weights are represented as sequences of 1s and 0s. The 1s and 0s in a JPEG image represent the intensity values of individual pixels, while the 1s and 0s in a weight matrix represent the parameters of a mathematical model.
During the training process, the model learns the weights that best capture the relationships between the input data (i.e., the images) and the desired output. This means that the weights encode information about the image data that was used to train the model.
The model can then use the learned weights to recreate the training data, or similar data, with a high degree of accuracy. This suggests that the weights are capturing the essential features of the image data and allowing the model to generalize to new, unseen data.
While the weights in a machine learning model are not literally stored as images, they are still encoding information about the image data that was used to train the model. This information can be used to recreate the training data, or similar data, with a high degree of accuracy, making the weights a form of image data in their own right.

Lacks line confidence. You have generally got things going in the right direction but you need to not make composite ("hairy") lines.
>>6489478
>>6489618
For coloring, you need to learn your tools a bit better. That as a completed image should only take you 3-4 hours of work at the absolute most. Things like using masks, auto-color tools, how to paint bucket effectively, and so on immensely helps with that kind of cel shading you're doing.
Try disabling Ctrl+Z for a month.


Basically your problem is that you are taking too long to complete each stage of a drawing. Accept your imperfections with the knowledge that producing art faster makes you better.
Making 5, increasingly-detailed sketches overlaid on top of each other using confident strokes takes less time than the 2-3 you did there using unconfident strokes.

Additionally your commission sheet needs to have its basics easily grasped from a twitter/deviantart/etc thumbnail. Offered levels of polish and prices primarily. Never use "percentages" to change pricing, and discounts look better than additional fees.

Try to blink the most you can. Basically our eyes tend to blink less when staring at a computer so trying to protect the eyes and keeping them lubricated is your best bet. Also taking a break every once in a while to walk around (good for the muscle) will give your eyes a break.
Then blue filters and lower brightness (if possible) to reduce the damage from the screen.
You won't turn up blind if you don't follow these steps but you can give your eyes enough damage for you to have a hard time walking around without glasses

Eyes
Feet
Neck

If you are a /beg/inner or /int/ermediate in art, please use this thread to post pieces for critique or ask for advice.
Use this thread instead of making new threads or post in the drawthread with fundamental exercises.

RESIZE YOUR IMAGES TO ~1000 PIXELS wide using one of the following methods:
1. screenshot the image and post that instead
2. change camera capture settings to something smaller
3. send to computer and resize in MSPaint

READ THE STICKY:
Completed: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1uwaXKU7ev6Tw_or__o8ARpUb6r2rCZYJGqwSFV9AD98/edit
New collaborative sticky (anyone can edit): https://hackmd.io/UMnZVhNITW-T2wZpHw6d0Q
Old: http://www.squidoo.com/how-to-draw-learn

RECOMMENDED BOOKS FOR BEGINNERS:
Read the sticky

TRY TO BE ACTIVE AND GIVE PEOPLE SOME FEEDBACK.
When giving feedback, avoid vague "advice" - point what's wrong and try to give the anon you're quoting a clear direction to improve their art (study heads < watch THIS VIDEO about head structure, read THIS SECTION of THIS ARTIST'S BOOK, etc).
You, feedback seeking anon, should also try to be clear and concise when asking for critique/help. When posting your artwork, say what you want help with, and what's your goal with the study/artwork.

posts.com:
>>6512980
Dont do hatching and crosshatching if you are going to scribble and not care about any of the lines.

- scribbling outside of lines should never happen. you routinely have lines crossing into other parts of the drawing. This is childlike mistakes coloring outside the lines tier. Easy fix is to practice line control. drawabox is a meme, but has stolen practice exercises in the first chapter or two for line control, ghosting lines, etc.
- lines are just thrown randomly without regards for the contour or plane of the object and routinely do not start or end at edges of plane they are rendering. its everywhere, but look right side vertical. the lines are so random in where they start and end even from line to line.
- spacing matters. you are creating gradients with line width and space between them. close together is darker. they should get farther apart as you go to imply the gradient of fading out to white or lighter shade. take horizontal sections at the top - you wanted it to be darker on the right curved side, but just add more lines randomly. its 'whiter' on the left, but the spacing is random. it then gets scribbly and darker but then randomly light in middle with the drastic change in spacing of lines. it doesnt read like light. just scribbles.
- cross hatching is a technique. its not just random lines. a good starting rule of point is to make your vertical and horizontals. once laid down pattern, angle so you hit every corner of the boxes. look at crosshatching up top. its just random angled lines. the spacing is drastically different every line. its just thrown lines with no thought.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QJXCw9J9eFI

go through old richard friend archives. these arent random lines. they require thought. You are on the right path, but you are in a rush. inking is time consuming process.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6516392
>i can envision something but it only appears for a split second before going away
I think that's normal though. You need to draw something several times to solidify your understanding of that thing, and by understanding it, you solidify it in your mind as well. It's easier to imagine an apple and rotating it in your head than it is to do the same with a car engine. The apple you've seen a million times, seen it from different angles, you've touched it, felt it's weight, tasted it, etc. The engine you've most likely only seen briefly a couple of times over your lifetime. Your understanding of the objects is completly different. Often we want to draw things we know exists, but don't really have a good understanding of what they really are. So we end up with this brief 'glimpse' of that thing, rather than the actual thing. Also, understanding how one things works often helps you understand how other things work. Knowledge builds on knowledge. This is why a broad visual library is such an important thing. At least that's my understanding as a /beg/.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6516419
>Like as if its an actual picture
If I want to yeah.
Usually though I can just "feel" something in my mind. But also I can imagine the depth of things, when I draw I try to really understand how everything fits into place and how certain parts will come closer or move further away from ones eyes.
>or can you only know/think about it from the description itself
No
I was a bit confused from your other post and it seemed like you could 'see' things but I think I know what you mean because honestly I never have a "description" in my mind. Sometimes if I want to be consistent I can note it, but honestly the picture comes first and then I describe it with words. The only time it goes the other way is if I'm trying to think of something new and interesting.

I don't think this means it's over for you though. As vivid as my imagination is, my drawings rarely match what I see and it's usually pretty vague, and even if I can fuckin imagine an apple or intricate object, the picture is not as clear as it seems if I actually try to focus on anything. Usually it changes entirely and it's frustrating. My drawings are not a direct translation from the pictures in my head, rather these are both expressions of my imagination and are not necessarily connected, they both come from the same source though (Thinking of something)

>>6516604
>>6516632
one thing is that you've both misinterpreted the orientation of her pelvis and ribcage, they're not parallel. Her ribcage is leaning away, so we shouldn't see the the top plane in a simplified form. Keep in mind tho that you shouldn't lean the ribcage tooo far back: She IS leaning forward so the ribcage will be more parallel with the viewer than normal. It's just that if you lean it too far forward, you're removing the Curve of the pose.

>>6516691
If the smudging was unintentional, you can place a piece of paper under your hand so you don't accidentally smudge the lines underneath, although that piece of paper can lift off some of the graphite itself. You may want to get a kneaded eraser, it can lift off the graphite without tearing the paper. You can also form it into a point to erase small details. Steven Zapata's YouTube channel has some great videos on using graphite pencils. The face and hair look really great.

posts.com:
>>6506446
gotcha. forgive me if you know all this, but just so we're on the same page:
not sure what resources you're using to study with but they should cover thinking about the figure in terms of it's component 3d 'forms', i.e. the ribcage, pelvis, head, two forms for each arm and leg, hands and feet. this is a 'constructive' approach to figure drawing that has you orient these 3d forms on the page in positions corresponding to what you see in the reference. it feels basically the same as posing an action man as you get better at drawing 3d objects (boxes, spheres, basic perspective).
so anyway, all that is a long way to set up that when I say 'an oval for the ribcage', try to visualise the ribcage in the figure you're drawing and mark that down as an oval on the page, and do something similar for all the forms in the figure. loomis and hampton and vilppu can all teach you what shapes you can use.

>>6506442
fair enough, whatever works for you.
but I'll say that I felt much the same way. the first couple of days drawing in silence were like scraping nails across a chalk board. but after not too long a clarity set in and I'm able to focus a lot better now. I'm not able to overthink in the silence because all of my attention is turned to the task of drawing (when all is going well).
so it went: 50% drawing, 50% yt/music, 0% bullshit thoughts
to: 50% drawing, 50% bullshit thoughts
to: 100% drawing, 0% bullshit thoughts
but the process of getting to that point takes time, is painful and I'm not always there, you have to stay vigilant and keep on yourself to focus on the drawing at hand. it's tough! but when you're 100% in that zone, like a surfer in the tube like in surfs up, nothing feels better.

don't know your particular circumstance, maybe you've got adhd or what have you, but I can say for me it was probably a simple case of frying my brain with constant stimulation. checking the phone first thing when you wake up etc..

Yes, but you need to be able to understand each part of the body like a 3d form. Not perfectly, just in simple terms. See picrel. >>6512652
I would recommend starting with just changing a limb or two to start with. You can also draw a reference from a different angle. Re-drawing a figure from memory helps too. Redrawing something you just drew shows you what you need to work on.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6512542
Getting a full figure down quickly helps. Once you can see the whole figure, it's easier to notice what is off. With less strokes on the page it's easier to fix the mistakes too. With a gesture drawing approach likes Glenn Vilppus, about 30 seconds is enough to get the major masses and limbs down. At that point I just check that the hips are at about halfway of the length of the figure and visually measure that it's around 7 to 8 heads tall, that's usually enough. For longer drawings or harder poses, more time is spent double checking stuff. You may find you keep making the same proportional mistakes, so that's something you can study and be on the lookout for.
A lot of the time you have to deal with foreshortened limbs and overlapping forms so it takes a lot of practice. There is also choosing what to exaggerate or idealize. For example, you can make the legs longer and it will usually look better, so when in doubt you can make them a bit longer.

posts.com:
>>6500480
depends if you are practicing right or just mindlessly get it done mentality etc. if you dont actively do anythign to improve and just repeat osme exercise you arent really sure why you are doing, you obviously wont improve even after hundreds of hours. if you slow down and analyze your practice exercises and actively look for mistakes and correct them, then you should improve.

for example, if you are doing ellipses or line weight or feathering/crosshatching and just scribble lines, thats not accomplishing anything. you are finishing the exercise, but its the same mistakes as the day before. you just wasted 15 minutes doing it or whatever.

when im in portrait mode, i'll do loomis heads from free references and full construction, etc. takes about half hour to do a head or two, depending on angle/difficulty/if i render it at all. the point is i am focusing on measurements, anatomy and actively measuring and trying to improve my portraits and construction. i'm not just filling a page with doodle heads and calling it practice. sometimes ill do the literal loomis plates.

practice makes perfect, but practicing wrong will always be wrong.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6500540
I am doing the best to improve as quickly as I can regarding what I want to get competent at (general character design, lineart, detailing, dynamic poses, explicit coom, hands, foreshortening, faces and expressions, and related while also ignoring stuff like rendering, environments, mecha, etc. for now just to get good faster at character art), so internalizing and practicing often core techniques and methods is a must for consistent and increasing quality in what I produce. So you can't say I am someone who just draws a full page of mindless Loomis heads and call it a day since my focus is clear from the start, tho I might need to produce more finished pieces and learn how to doodle just for fun in general as well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: So when it comes to drawing from life, is it best to break the subject down into simple shapes/forms and then "draw what you see"?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6508095
It's best, no a necessity, to start with blocking the drawing in the space of your canvas/paper. Measure from top to bottom, left to right and do a sort-of connect the dots lines to block the general "shape" your drawing will take up. Once your done with that and know for a fact that no part of the model's head/limbs will be cut outside of the canvas then you move in with large free strokes that give you the feeling of the pose and it's gesture. It is best to make them with your shoulder/elbow. It really doesn't matter what the subject matter is, a couple of cans have a line of placement and so-on. THEN you start breaking the subject/model into simple shapes on top of the free lines and IN the confined space you mapped in the begging.

>what's the correct resolution for 1000x1000 pixels?
1000x1000 pixels is always going to be 1000x1000 pixels, no matter what value you put in dpi, it wont add or remove pixels from your image, you can always change it afterwards, its information for printing, it only make sense if you have physical dimension too. for example 210 x 297 mm (a4 print size) printed with 300dpi, you will need roughly 2400x3500 pixels image to print it that way, but if you want to print lower quality 150dpi at same a4 size then you only need around 1200x1700 pixels image.

Senseless question. Understandable, because no one seems to know what that means, but it's easy.

The resolution is a value only useful for the printer. This value can be even deleted; in this case, the printer will assume a default value.
A resolution of 254 means that 100 pixel are equal to 1 centimeter.
A resolution of 100 means that 100 pixel are equal to 1 inch.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I started up drawing recently (< 2 months ago), and currently trying to understand how do I get proportions in human body right.
My approach is quite mechanical in nature, as in I either sketch from photos, or do rough sketches from imagination and then approach them with ruler to check, if I got proportions correctly.
Question is - perhaps there's some other method to that, and if so, can someone point me to that?
Any general advice on the matter is also appreciated.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6513012
its usually relative to the head size. you can adjust proportions on head heights as well if you want someone heroic looking or for fashion designers they use like 10-12 head height and super long legs - but it would all be relative to the size of the head you draw.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i8CSKor2GNw is a fashion designer showing how to adjust a normal reference to a 10 head size. she discusses head heights, relative anatomy markings that coincide with the head heights, etc. you may not want to do fashion, but its still basically the jist of this.

but generally, youll have head heights for your character and then adjust proportions based on that. this doesnt change anatomy per se, but how they look when drawn. super heroes are like 8 heads usually, fashion croquis are 10-12, etc. children have different head proportions due to large heads/small bodies/still developing if you are doing children.

da vinci virtruvian man is probably most famous proportions image and it shows off a lot of basic anatomy and reference marks. ive attached a generic image of head heights though.

for the landmarks, 1 head is jaw to top of head. 2 heads usually hits at the nipples or around there (hanging breasts, muscled pecs, etc might put nipples above or below the line). 3 heads is usually hitting the belly button. 4 hits the crotch. the legs usually where adjustments are made for total head height proportions (8 for 'ideal/heroic', 10 for fashion, etc with longer legs for more heads). 5 is probably mid thigh, 6 the knees, 7 high ankle, and 8 would be the bottom of feet.

other landmarks can be learned. for instance, the wrists hanging at side hit just below crotch or deltoid lines up with nipples, elbows at belly button, etc. things like reilly rhythms teach more advanced relationships and lines that can help map out the way a body connects.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=djHcqOjAaoY does loomis body and discusses it with landmarks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6514014
just master studies and analyze their art. what do they do that makes it unique. like pen and ink you can look at so many options. thickness of lines. do they crosshatch or is it all hatches. do they obey perspective or do they only obey contours. do they use pure black and white or is there a wash or other greytone from diluted ink, etc. thats just the technical inking part on how they generate the lines. what they render and how they render it comes in.

for colored pieces, the color pallet is a large factor on top of the medium. a water color piece vs gouache or copics. a muted pallet vs vibrant ghibli poster paint style piece. ghibli or old disney cartoon style, for example, can be applied to any real world reference if you understand the simplifying of plants and basic colors used. very easy to study and learn as a simple example.

its not so much just 'copy' them as understanding what you are copying and why they draw or color or do the things they do. why did they crosshatch that. why did they dry brush that part only. why are they using such a dark pallet, etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Whatever you do, keep in mind you need energy to draw.

- The job must either be stress-free, short OR seasonal. For instance, my friend works at an oil extraction platform. He works like crazy for 15 days straight, living at the plant. Then, he takes 15-day breaks, which you could use to draw.

- Leeching off of your parents is one thing, becoming 100% independent is another. If you can afford to just contribute to the house expenses, you don't need THAT fancy of a job, just the bare minimum to not be deadweight at home while you work on your skills. Remember, in you case getting enough time to draw is more important than getting large sums of money, otherwise you wouldn't be an aritst.

- Once you start working, in case it's a daily job, make sure you draw BEFORE work so you don't arrive home with no energy to do anything. Go to bed early, wake up early, drawdrawdraw. If you can draw DURING work, that's a different story, but doing both is still great mileage.

Good luck, nonners.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6470632
the eyebrows arent in sync with the eyes hence the delayed action feeling

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6470632
refine the chin placement it follows a rigid pathing make it follow some sort of smooth arch it'll look more natural that way
the bangs have a nice delayed action to them good job : D
also i'd suggest drawing the ears as well even if they're just place-holders cause they'll help keep the head shap from warping with each succesive frame
hold the looking at camera frame for longer before transitioning into the forward leaning motion also make the head a bit farther back in that frame or push it slightly forward in the final pose cuz if you're leaning forward you bend forward slightly rather than rotation forward while being stuck in the same location
also do the eyes completely open first and add the blink after you've smoothened the movement
i get the vibe you're going for but i think you over-stepped in that bit
as is anime eyes are already notoriously difficult to place properly since their orientation depends on the camera angle rather than some defined points in space

you have long way to grow young grass-hopper

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6491351
The first several frames should look like a ball (yours appears out of nowhere at speed)
Try having fewer frames and less squash when it impacts the ground
It should not slow out from the bounce, so try removing a few frames after the impact
You have blank frames, which is causing blinking; clean it up
As the ball approaches its apex, it should slow down because of gravity, so add more frames. At the top of its bounce it should become its roundest

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6515254

coders are getting culled long before animators, and lets be real, animation requires way too much control for Ai to probably ever be reliable to use (especially after they get cucked out of their training data in the future). if you're actually a good animator that can get hired for doing animatics / key / breakdown frames or directorial positions, the jobs won't disappear. in-betweeners, colourists and clean-up artists will either have their job drastically downsized or taken out entirely.

there's already so little actually good 2d animated content that gets released every year, just due to the time it takes to produce. there's the very real possibility of a boom / second golden age in animation just from the speed of production we would get. i can imagine a lot of feature length, traditionally animated 2D films (not the shitty fake 2d that always takes its place)

also Ai actually understanding complex movement enough to replicate laws of physics consistently in an appealing manner, enough to compete with what humans have achieved in the past.. i don't see it happening desu, not for 10+ years at least.

>Between two to three weeks, usually when you reach level 3. Even unapproved submissions count toward your streak!

>draw in sketchbook
>perfect circles, drawing from the shoulder naturally, no chicken scratches. Completely natural, quick and easy.

a guy once just seemed lonely and wanted to talk to me about his dog. Just treat them as you would if you were working behind the counter in retail (this honestly is what helped me stop having autism spaghetti, people just want to talk and be kind to each other mostly, and it's likely they want to try and be your friend so you just have to accept that and try to keep your distance relatively). Respond kindly and say things like "yeah I had a pet like that, I can relate" and if you think of something to ask that you're actually interested in like "have you trained your dog to do any tricks?" then ask but don't try and have an extended conversation, just like "Well that's cool"

Idk man I'm on the spectrum somewhere.

Tell me what he wants to talk about, he probably just wants you to be yourself, meaning if you don't wanna talk, be brief. I try and type half the words they do so the conversation peters out generally idk

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6512060
>have fun talking to me
I think that's a literally impossible goal with a stranger and you'll be causing a weird conversation if you try and make jokes or relate to them on a deeper level than you know them, the most you can do is match them. If they ask a question, then answer and if it leads to another question in your mind then ask. The conversation should always just be respectful and friendly, like someone wants to buy something from your IRL shop, and maybe they notice you're wearing a nice shirt and they comment on it or something so you respond and say you like their shoes or something. It's not really something you can quantify or prepare yourself for, some people are weird, some people are awesome. Just try to be respectful and truthful in the moment. Trying not to drop your spaghetti and say something weird for me literally just took watching my coworkers deal with the weirdos (I worked near a hospital). Smiling and nodding.
Man I am not a good person to ask.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6512060
cont I guess
>They'd mention one thing that sparked my interest, but by the time I wrote a question about it, they'd already move on to a slightly different subject or ask a question on their own.
it sounds like they want to do the talking, so don't worry about it. Human interaction takes getting used to and it's not something to be fearful of as long as you're being friendly and responding to things they ask and not treating them like you haven't got the time (unless you really haven't)
I empathise with your thoughts a lot and it's how I felt when I first had to talk to customers IRL "am I doing this right" "is this too rude or dismissive" and really the only answer is to use informal friendly language and be truthful in the moment, that's all you can do, and the self doubt can fuck right off because you're doing your best. do it enough and you won't even worry if you're doing it right.

>>6513704
Professional anon here:
I have the cintiq 16 and I think it's basically all around the best tablet out there. Only downside is that it has no built in buttons.

It's a decent size, not too big, not too small, very portable if you want to shift stuff around. Screen resolution isn't super hd, but I don't think you need it. The screen is just small enough that you'll probably never get close enough to it to really notice the pixel density.

Furthermore, this is an underrated fact but it's extremely important. I think it's a really durable tablet. The cintiq 16 pro is nice and all, but it's way over priced and far less durable than the 16. The glass is very thin and the pixels are lamenated to the glass so just imagine drawing on your regular monitor with a wacom pen all day, yeah you're going to fuck up your monitor. that's what the 16 pro is like.

Lastly is the price. It's not cheap, but it's not overly expensive either if you plan on really using it.

Overall, if you want wacom's precision and you want a screen tablet. I think the 16 is all around the best for most artists.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6514855
I genuinely cannot fathom why people get in a tisy over slight paralax. It's absolutely baffling to me. I even explicitly calibrate my pen so the cursor is slightly offset so I can better see what I'm doing. I've convinced a few of my coworkers to do the same and they haven't gone back. I'd recommend you try it too, you'd be surprised how little parallax really matters.

But anyway, the main point I brought up about the laminated display is that it's extremely easy to damage the pixels with such thin glass. Even just your light palm pressure on the screen is enough to damage it over time. The cintiq 22pro doesn't have this issue because the glass is thicker.

posts.com:
>>6509159
>but would that work with paper as thick as cardstock and Bristol boards?
Yep, literally what they're made for. Caveat: If your pencil sketch is messy, it will be a little difficult. In that case, here's what you do:
>scan drawing
>flip drawing
>print
>trace using carbon paper/tracing paper
>transfer
>ink that

Alternatively:
>scan
>fix your dirty ass drawing in Photoshop
>print with adjusted contrast
>put under lightbox and pretend like you know how to draw without erasing 500 times and drawing the world's messiest lines

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6513630

Not the same guy, but in my experience, gouache has a pretty brutal learning curve, because it never "sets" even after it dries, so if you have too much water on your brush, you can easily reactivate it and have it bloom, mix, lift off, or turn into mud.

This also limits your layering because a lot of fresh wet paint over dry paint will reactivate the old paint and turn it into soup. So, if you make a serious mistake, it's better to wipe it away and repaint that area, than to try and paint over your mistake. Fortunately that's pretty easy to do.

On the plus side, provided you're working on decent paper, you have basically endless opportunities to correct your mistakes, and the opacity of the paint will cover up any stains left on the paper from earlier attempts.

To me, the most important thing is to control the amount of water in your brush; too much water and it makes a mess, too little and it won't go on smoothly. I have also trained myself to step away and let areas dry before adding another layer; otherwise they just mix on the sheet. Fortunately, this doesn't take long.

Also, every single paint will have a different consistency, from smooth to gooey, so you'll have to get used to that too. Some blues and greens get weird.

Once you get over that learning curve, though, gouache is really powerful and fun. There's a reason it was one of the defaults for commercial artists alongside acrylic, until computers took over.

I've attached one of my pieces so you can see my skill-level, and judge for yourself whether I'm worth listening to.

>>6513630
I find it easiest of acrylic, gouache and water color. acrylic dries way too fast and you sort of have to do it all that session or waste paint. gouache can reactivate and come back to whenever. if i have to go do something else or the painting not coming together, i can just put lid on teh paint and come back the next day. very convenient. similar to water color but not as messy. can do wet layer or full opaque layer right away depending on what you want to achieve. as someone else said, you can mess up reactivating lower layers, but its hard to fuck up since you can just remove it or let it dry and paint over again since gouache so opaque you can literally just cover old layer with a single brush stroke if you dont water the paint down. lot of options. i recommend starting with it. pick up a himi jelly gouache set for cheap. comes with some brushes and pallet and all paint laid out for you in containers. i started with acrylic though, so had some knowledge of brush strokes, mixing, color theory, etc.

>>6514221
I have tried quite a lot of pencils, probably spent like 60 bucks trying stuff out.

For wood pencils I like Faber-Castell thr best, judt all around solid and good hardbess choice.

Lead holder hands down KOH-I-NOOR versatil 5900, absolutely amazing to draw with, indestructible and feels great.

A good mechanical pencil was hard to find, tried a lot of shit, including obscure japanese ones. I really wanted a mechanical pencil that felt as good as the KOH-I-NOOR, but none came close, especially not at 0.3 mm.
The MUJI low gravity mechanical pencil has very high build quality but I didn't like the how the metal grip feels on the skin. Good choice if you don't mind that.
I settled on the Pentel P203. It's just hard plastic, but very precise, no wiggling of any kind. Just solid performance, despite lacking some appeal.

As for mines, KOH-I-NOOR for the lead holder, Pentel for the mechanical (their 2B are amazing).
Dishonorable mentions:
ZEBRA Mechanical pencil tect 2 way - The auto advance "feature" makes it wiggle around in your hand and shift it's center of gravity constantly.

STAEDLER 0.3 mechanical pencil - Absolute trash, the mine is wiggling like crazy it feels like putting a 0.3 mine in a 0.5.

STAEDLER mechanical pencil mines - feels like you're writing with rubber, they jump around the paper (for printing paper) and make actual sqeaking noises.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Best pencil I've ever used is the Zebra DelGuard. I like the springy lead that helps it not break so easily. Refilling it can be a pain in the dick sometimes but all in all it's a pretty good pencil for my own needs, but I also don't really do any shading and only outline or thumbnail. Shading is an area that it lacks in quite heavily but everything else seems pretty good for a pencil you can get at most hobby shops. Lead stays in place once you get it loaded and you don't feel any shifting or rattling or anything like that, unless the lead inside breaks of course. Can't comment on the eraser since I use a block or kneaded eraser instead.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6514831
I've got a lot of experience here over the years. I'll try to break some of the main names down that I've used.

- standard Bic Ballpoint Pen is a classic and very underrated, but of course terrible in a professional setting. If you can git gud with one of these, most other pens will be child's play.

- Sakura Micron Pens are good all rounders. They get a lot of praise and memes made about them because of how anime centered the brand is but honestly they are very good pens for what they are, especially at the price point, and doubly so if you get them on sale. Big range of sizes, as small as .003mm and up to like 2mm I think? Also they come in colors too but the majority are only 0.5mm. The thin ones are very brittle though so be careful.

- Sakura Micron Brush Pens are okay if you have nothing else. Better than a sharpie, but you should definitely look into getting some other form of brush pen for big areas you'd need in solid black. Ink strokes are very streaky and it's very noticeable in the light. Not for fine lining unless you have the steady hands of a brain surgeon.

- Pentel Brush Pen (hard plastic kind, with the traditional bic style cap) is a very good pen as well and comes in a variety of sizes, but the medium size specifically is the best in my experience. They're also refillable via cartridges which is nice. When you learn the brush control it's an incredible pen to use but brushes aren't everyone's cup of tea. Roughly the size of a regular ink pen but a little thicker.

2nd post incoming, ran out of space

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6514831
>>6514882

- Kuretake brush pens are okay but I personally found it to be a little bit overrated. They dry up quickly in storage too, as I had all mine for just under 2 years before I had to replace them and didn't even use them every day. It's a style of pen in between pen and brush, but honestly I found the ink to be inferior to the Pentel and the Microns. It wants to play in this middle ground but doesn't excel at either side. But this might be an unfair judgement, as the Kuretake I got were from Hobby Lobby so I don't know if they're the real deal or just some manufactured cash grab attempt with a brand name. Quite a big pen though,

- Copic Multiliners are cool but I also find these to be inferior to the Microns. Their all-aluminum design is neat and flashy, but it's just paying extra for the same quality of work you'd get from the Microns. Both of their inks fulfill largely the same thing. The Copic multiliners are refillable as well but a refill costs about as much as a brand new Micron so pick your poison I guess. These are significantly thicker than a Micron so if you're using a bag for your pens you won't be able to fit as many in there.

- Pentel Brush Pen (soft plastic kind with a plain black rigid cap and a red ring around it) is an okay pen, nothing to write home about but also no glaring flaws. One of mine leaks though but I chalk that up to me having it fucking forever. The ink is a little streaky but also a little too wet for my tastes, which is not a good combination as you'd need at least 2 layers to get a flat black. Has a massive ink reserve in the rubberish housing and you squeeze it to add more ink to the chamber which flows into the bristles. These do have some cool utility though, as you can get some really cool dry brush effects with minimal effort if you let the ink run out a little and only squeeze in just enough to wet the tip again. Not worthless, but a far cry from the top as well. It's as big as the Kuretake.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6514885
Copic does have two advantages over Micron in my opinion.
One, their Sepia, Brown and Wine colors are great for colored line art in marker illustrations.
And two, there's no pirate Copic multiliners yet, but Amazon is packing with Micron clones that aren't anywhere near as good as the real deal.

The problem is, so many adults (and children, even worse) nowadays have been conditioned by smart phones and social media to need constant dopamine hits. Anything requiring sustained concentration is thus discouraged. They are also likely on some type of mind-altering prescription drug(s) with a list of side effects longer than a telephone book. If you eat well (cut out sugar and excessive carbs), get enough sleep and don't drug yourself into a stupor you should be able to learn faster and better than you could as a child.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6516485
>less afraid of failure
This is a big one. Adults get caught up in judgment, which can be good for evaluating work that matters, but terrible for practice and progress.
>oh fuck, that head study looked like shit, I don't want to do it again because it will look like shit too and I'll further doubt my abilities... let me just go cry about how i'll never make it
Kids look at their shitty drawing and just marvel that they were able to put an image on the paper at all, and then just keep doing it over and over, picking things up as they go. If you can shed the judgment, it will help a lot, and a key to this is to produce tons of stuff, so any one failed drawing might be forgotten about entirely in a few days, and hopefully soon replaced by one that you're somewhat satisfied with. Once you can reach the point of producing satisfying works on relatively regular occasion, the thrill of trying to come up with your next great piece becomes addictive, and each failed attempt in between is just a speedbump as opposed to something you fixate on as the be-all, end-all of your failed attempt at art.

posts.com:
This thread is dedicated to master studies, where you copy artwork you admire as a form of study. They are the quickest way to improve and learn about any fundamental you are having problems with. If you need to work on your hands, copy hands from other artists, and if you're having trouble with rendering, make careful studies of paintings with lighting you admire. Studies can be quick or long. You can even copy anatomy books like Bridgman, Morpho, and Hogarth. The type of studies you want to do depend on your personal goals and the types of problems you are grappling with.

Artists of all levels are welcome. Critiques and redlines are encouraged.

Recommended watching:

>>6466732
I don't think you really understand what the term "master study" means judging by the crap you've been spamming anon.

A "master study" implies you're studying from an artist you consider well-rounded and of a higher, established skill level. You do so in order to break down and understand the process behind the picture, akin to reverse-engineering it. It has nothing to do with them being born centuries ago or having their works on a museum's wall. Even studying someone else's study can be considered a master study.
The medium and style said artist is using only matters to you. If you believe Miyazaki's drawings possess something you want to extract and instill into your own art, then he is a master to you and studying his work counts as a master study. Same goes for some famous Twitter artist you look up to.

Forcing an anti-Japanese culture narrative or pretending to objectify what should be valued as masterful or not in the end just tells more about you people's petty complexes more than anything else.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6473037
He's showing the front plane of the pectorals. This plane is bounded laterally by a line from the clavicle (specifically, the point on the front at which the clavicle curves backward) to the bottom outer limit of the pectoral (just a little below/outside the nipple). From that bottom/outer point, an oblique line going toward the point of the shoulder is the base of another triangular plane, which is the side plane of the pectoral.

>>6504329
>I want to get better at painting. My skill in line art and painting arent equal and its time to fix it.
if your goal/assignment isn't to use a particular construction method for now, and you can just copy what you see, then I recommend mentally detaching it from your drawing habits. think more about shapes and edges instead of lines, especially during your block in phase; the whole picture as irregular, interlocking, straight-edged shapes. think about it in terms of light and shadow if the source allows. block ins are the most important thing to get right. mark tennant is an awesome painter who basically just does block ins.

I can give more info or critique if you want, but here's are some lines I drew over your (modified) ref to illustrate. the yellow is an envelope with too many edges, and the green is to sort of highlight what I would casually consider to be barriers between light and shadow.

dorian iten has some really good videos about it that I recommend. I find that over time, his advice is what sticks for me and has helped me the most. his advice helped me a lot with accuracy, identifying value relationships, and thinking about process.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zZ0lz7W0CYs

Bottom 3rd of the face is HUGE, more than justifiable accounting for perspective and open mouth, and not cute. Shaving a little off the bottom would work wonders. The adjusted proportions will fix >>6514640

The lack of perspective play on the mouth is a missed opportunity, the curvature of the top lip and teeth should be especially pronounced in this view. Bring the tongue more to a point, google "Sexy tongue" and you'll see plenty of examples.

Fingers are blocky and inelegant, front and center puts them on show. Fingertips; As you approach any form of sideview there's a slope towards the nail bed. Don't need to render knuckles but most important is shaving a little off the sides from middle section of the fingers onwards; Middle finger loses some mass on both sides while the others can get shaved down on the sides that would touch the middle finger. This gives an impression of the natural curvature of the fingers. My ability to draw thumbs are shit, but that don't look right at al.

Legs look wonky, I'd bet money you didn't plan them before the crop.

>>6505190
I don't think the foreshortening really works with this image. One, his leg is in a very, very uncomfortable position for it to be twisting out towards the viewer as it is. Two, from a compositional standpoint, we tend to follow the gaze from a character in a piece toward whatever they're looking at. As he's posed, the line of his gaze is broken by his knee. It makes the composition feel a bit cramped and less interesting than it could be.

Personally, I would do something like this. Repositioning the legs gives some room in the composition to build up a more engaging scene with the environment. But ymmv.

>>6506654
I've only just decided to dabble in coom shit so I'm new.

>Why do you like coom art?
There's a lot to miss out on if you avoid nudity, which is what coom artists are obviously going to touch on very frequently. And because most of their work is often going to include skin tight clothes or none at all, their well rendered drawings make for pretty good references. Not to suggest I wouldn't use the more reliable IRL references, but fictional art sparks a lot more inspiration out of me and it's much more appealing to stare at than real porn imo. Violent scenarios are also easier for me to look at if fictionally depicted.
>What do you think coom art will be like in the next 5 years?
I'm going to bet on the regression bit as >>6508005 suggested, or at least hope so. I'm not even against degeneracy like hyper shit or even shit itself but I still hope people remember to appreciate tame subjects as though you're embracing nature for what it is.
I have similar sentiments to >>6507919 though because there are people in the nsfw community that literally do have a moral problem with smaller chested (not freakishly huge titties) or aged up fictional characters. No interest in consooming or creating loli shit whatsoever, however seeing as it can be considered as legally questionable as actual children being abused and the filmed distribution of such, I wouldn't put past the possibility anon stated.
>What are your coom art goals?
Well, I want to attract a decently sized audience of whom I'm looking for, without much pandering. Sticking to creating vanilla fanart is good enough for me. I also want to try animation once I get the hang of it. Ideally, it would be possible to make money off of it (I won't lie, /ic/ has made me feel quite hopeful). Hell, I wouldn't complain if it became a career for me given the pay is worth it. I already have my own sfw art goals anyway so if all goes wrong, I say nuke it + continue working stable jobs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6511119
Outside of Christianity (and possibly even then), religious art only works if you're into what you're making with some sincerity. People like collecting artwork of deities, ideas, talismans, and relatable experiences. I make a lot of them with the intention of being worn or to decorate an altar / sacred space. I sell both online and locally, but you could do well by just selling online. The biggest part that you would need to remember is that people will absolutely talk to you about your process, moreso than any other art. Your experiences are a bigger part of the selling point than you'd expect from other niches. If you say you aren't religious/spiritual and you were just making it for fun, they'll steer you into thinking you were touched or possessed, so it's better to nail down your narrative, real or fake. This is because they treat this art as an expression of God, and the market is always hungry for new work. It's the niche where I've seen art valued on a visceral level, and probably the only niche where AI won't replace anyone and settle in as a tool of surrealist visions.
Christian art requires more distance from coom, as I'm sure you'd imagine. I do have Christians who buy my stuff, but they're moreso from the mysticism or multi-path background. You can have thousands of religion and spirituality-based artists, but they all will do well as long as they're persistent because there needs to be art that caters to every personality.
It's probably the easiest niche to do well in, but the hardest to maintain because you'll need a spiritual connection of your own, or a good masquerade.

I think i hit limit growth. I cant grow past around 2.2k followers (on twitter)

I post frequently and get around 600 likes on a good day but followers are going up very slowly.

Should i draw for a different audience? More original content? Or should i just try to improve my skills?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6434940
I think 600 likes for 2k is a very good amount. Theres people with 10k who get less than that.
The usual tips are the same as always, drawing OCs from larger users, try nsfw, fotm, keep posting a lot and such. You are already improving as you keep drawing and posting new content, your followers notice that.

I think the luck factor is very important. Being in the right spot at the right time. How do RTs from big accounts work for you? Do they get lots of likes/follows? If thats so, aim for that.

Me personally cant grow by my own anymore as Im shadowbanned. I draw nsfw, not hardcore stuff though, just nudes. Everytime I post something new, my tweet gets hidden for at least 12 hours. It isnt showing in the search option, not by keywords, neither tags. I rely just on my own followers and luck. And even my own followers dont see my posts most of the time. I have 3k, but only getting 30 likes or so because of this. The moment another account RTs me, I can reach 3k likes. Thats really awful and discouraging.

I wish there were other places for promote yourself instead of depending 100% on that.

>>6451767
I dont remember right now in previous versions, but you can press 'P' as a hotkey for the color picker

>>6451775
When Im first sketching a scene it looks kinda similar, its my style. But its been months since my last big draw. Think that I sculpt with my pen in ZBrush, so Im basically drawing in 3D, rotating 360º my figures and adjusting them on every angle, they need to look fine.

Creating 3D scenes instead of 2D, allows me to do many other things, like rotating over the scene, animating, scaling specific parts, changing the pose or working with cloth/fluid physics.

But the main reason for using them in interactive scenes inside Unreal is for example changing their clothes with particle effects, different hairstyles, or anything you can imagine inside a videogame.
Im still polishing my scenes but Im planning to make them downloadable with small minigames and such

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6428290
>It looks particularly bizarre to have the canvas and wood fins coming out of heavy iron/steel/whatever.
they are iron, on both of my designs, the lines are segments, but i can see why one could think they are made out of canvas
>also... why does it have regular ship screws?
because its also works as regular battleship if none of the anti gravitational fuel is available, the flight mode cannot be sustained forever too, because of the liquids properties (has to be kept at a certain temperature and mixture with gases to work/ overheating issues etc.)
>Show pipes or... something to differentiate from regular hull
i think its pretty distinctive from regular battlesip hulls, but i guess it could use more details, proruding pipes arent good for hydro/aerodynamics though., the fuel is highly explosive/hard to obtain aso it wouldnt be smart to have them visible, they are housed behind massive super thick armor plating behind the bublbs under the steering propeller arms, most of the magic is on the inside, like massive stabilising gyroscopes, special pipes and motors for the outside propeller gondolas.etc
also pic relatd are some earlier versions and a regular battleship

I was toying around with threads and I got it to look decent, though the perspective is off.
As for the texture, I made Triangle pattern and used the bend tool or w/e in Kirta since I was trying to see how it would look, trying to go for that camo netting pattern thats pretty hard to draw, In the end it was just a test, since I was learning about using textures and what not.
The hard part about the treads is that it it looks off if the perspective is off. It took me a bit to figure out how shade these and show that they are treads on the track, but you need a good underline or if not, dont strictly follow the underline if you know the perspective is off. I could fix it but I moved on for this until I get some coloring practice in.

posts.sub: Why is it so hard to find a tutor
posts.com:
I have seriously been trying to find a human art tutor for at least 4 years now. Everything out there seems to be either in person or specifies that it’s for children, the few people I could find seemed sketchy with no reference art to look at.
I am willing to pay and even then it’s not easy, and the few people I know who are great at drawing refuse to teach me regardless of how much I offer.

Flat out, I have not been able to teach myself. Nothing makes sense to me, video lessons haven’t helped, and I feel I need someone who can explain everything I’m doing wrong in detail and hold me accountable if I’m ever going to improve.

Where does one go to do s someone you can pay to do this? I attended a few community college art classes and those were of no help to me.

I’m tired of being insecure about my lack of talent and failing to learn even while practicing fundamentals on the regular. I need real guidance

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6513658

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6513668
Someone to teach you what you’re doing wrong

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Sorry to hear, dude. I'd help. Genuinely I would. My life is shit and I'm broke and lonely, but I've studied art for a long time and I have a handle on fundies. Not sure how we'd get in touch in this context though, and I fear I'm not the teacher type.

I will say that the most mileage i've gotten skill-wise has been doing life studies. Draw simple stuff on your desk every day. Helped me a ton. Also careful master studies , painting or drawing. Personal whatevers should be done in between studies. Get deep with a study then do a personal painting/drawing and then repeat.

Probably you should join a discord group if you can and try making connections there. I'm out of the loop with this shit but I hear there's good discord groups. Get out there and connect with enough people and get enough feedback and you're golden. I mean actually you probably shouldn't expect to be spoon fed stuff. What makes a great artist is the thinking they do on their own while picking apart this art thing. But everyone's different. A good tutor may genuinely be the ticket.

In any case, don't get discouraged and I wish you the best. I know its hard but considering you mention college, you're probably still pretty young. Don't be too hard on yourself and compare yourself to others too much.

If you're failing to grasp fundamentals despite practicing hmm...

Just like...draw THROUGH the form and really try to feel it. Break everything down into simple shapes and use the fewest marks possible. The key to good drawing and painting is being able to simplify. Learning to paint/draw is learning to see. Draw coke cans and stacked books on your desk and do 30 second gestures every day and legit copy by sight drawings or paintings by your heroes to get the feel for what they're doing.

Sorry for the novel but your post made me sad and I really hope you make it, anon.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
OP, do you put in the hours DAILY?

I am a language teacher and the only students I have who make actual progress are the ones who stay in touch with the language.
I am not teaching them even 10% of what they're learning, I'm only giving them corrections, saying "you should try X and Y instead of Z" and then they go and do that for 6 days of the week, before checking back with me on the 7th.
These are the ones who pick up on all the small tips I give, because they actually try and experience the problems, and when I give them instructions, they are not something that they have to LEARN, it's more like something they have to THINK ABOUT, NOTICE, and then correct, at least most of the time.

Comparatively, I have began music lessons recently, as a complete beginner.
In 2 months I have made a huge progress because I practice every day for 1 hour.
While most students my teacher has don't do their homework and are forced to do it during class time, wasting 1 hour of everyone's time by repeating scales, I grind those scales at home, ask my teacher about the points I'm struggling with, he listens to my whining and gives some points. I probably only practice for 5 minutes during his class, everything else is discussing what I can do on my own to progress, DESPITE the fact that I'm a beginner and am at the stage where a lot of hand-holding is necessary.

As a non-beginner, handholding should be minimal, only at key elements.

If you can identify with the study ethics I described above and still think a tutor would be your solution, THEN the problem becomes finding a good one, because most teachers are there for beginners, who are the ones who need the most instruction.

One suggestion I can give if there's no one to be found, is to participate in collaborative projects. Find people working on something and offer a hand, socialize, or just compare how other people treated the same subject as you in their part of the work, you can learn a thing or two.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6514161
That's a tough one, I go through the same issue and having 4~6 hours of productivity a day is something I consider a successful day, I'm slowly building it up from there.
The first step is either fixing your sleep schedule or finding a routine that you can follow regardless of time, starting at the time you wake up. It's harder, but possible if you plan your meals and have flexible IRL obligations.

>>6514174
That has to do with the anon I was responding to above.
Learning to LIMIT your daily study is also very important to avoid burnout and inefficient practice.
If you feel like 8 hours aren't taking you anywhere, limit your practicing hour to 3 a day. And find something else you can do with those 5 hours. Maybe it's working on a project for 3 hours and watching some tutorials/taking CONSCIOUS notes for 2 hours.
Maybe it's making a study plan so you can grind the next day with the certainty that you are doing structured learning.

The biggest enemy of progress is being impatient, you have to trust the method and let time do its thing.
But trusting the method is a daily struggle, we want to improve NOW. That's why so many gurus are always shilling meditation, because people need to learn winding down is part of the process.

Here's a video on why you should limit yourself, and being productive isn't always good:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TImmiAS1USQ

Here's a course some anon recommended to me two years ago and I've followed through, implementing a few of the methods described into my routine to stop living life under constant stress and impatience:
https://www.coursera.org/learn/learning-how-to-learn

IMPORTANT: Applying these concepts. Going "Ah, makes sense" and not attempting anything is also bad. Don't be an information hoarder. Think less about what is OPTIMAL and think about what is CONSISTENT.

posts.com:
>>6514161
By doing something you want to do. If it's a struggle to do this for art, then reconsider your priorities.
Blog time: I was your typical "bright" kid in school who got the praise and as a result never learnt how to study or practice, hit the wall that you do in late high school and my grades tanked because I didn't know how to actually apply myself. I graduated and without really thinking about it just dove into drawing. Even though I was/am definitely not a "disciplined" person, I didn't need to be because I just did what I felt like doing. I didn't study, I only drew what I wanted and yet I improved and continue to improve because I'm actively making things and striving to improve.

Here's the bit that may be relevant to you: if you have to force yourself then is it even a good idea to pursue art? I feel like there's not much point in doing art if you find yourself having to force yourself to draw. I don't mean if you're already a pro artist or whatever and need to force yourself to draw more to meet deadlines, I just mean in these earlier stages where you have no dependence on drawing and are at the stage where you should be doing it because you like it and are deciding whether you want to pursue it further.

Work ethic is only really needed when what you have to force yourself to do something unpleasant. If you enjoy what you do then work ethic is not a skill you need to hone. It may still be useful, ie to make yourself work even when you don't want to, but when most of the time you want to do the work most of the time you won't need to exercise discipline to get it done.

My tour through doing art has been rocky.
I went to an art school, but somehow managed to get all of the drawbacks and none of the benefits. Even now a decade later, my skills are not professional level and I'm still paying off the debt. I figure most would give up, I gave that a shot even, but I could never escape the craft. It was like trying to kill part of myself, I was a lesser man for the trouble. What keeps me going is a strong internal determination. I have no presence, no following and niche subject interests, but something inside of my heart won't let me quit. I can't, the very concept disgusts me.

posts.com:
>>6494108
Go for it man. I've studied with people who became successful artists starting at the age of 40 or 50, all the cynicism here is a meme. The field is hard but if you work at it and really think about the work you're doing and who it's for you can definitely find a niche.

The best advice I can give you is to try and find classes or studios by you. Just walk-ins for figure drawing, not an art school or anything like that. Self study can definitely work for some people but you'll always improve more efficiently if you're with a community and have people giving you live advice. Watching How to Draw streams and pirating art books is the fastest way to stagnate if you don't know exactly what you're doing.

Oh, i just paint where i sleep, and then I open the windows to ventilate the room, and put the painting on the balcony to dry.

So there are options, bro, if you really want to paint with oils! A separate room is not necessary.

>>6512951
I don't know if you're trolling, but I somewhat agree. It depends on what you mean by construction. The Loomis head is a fine way to *understand* the construction and proportions of the head but it's too difficult for beginners to draw correctly in any but the simplest views, and too much unnecessary work for experienced artists. This is how I feel about most of what's called "construction." Simple shapes and guidelines are useful. Visual mnemonic devices are also helpful. For drawing from imagination, it's easier and more practical to remember, "The head from the front resembles an egg turned upside down" than to carve out some complex 3D wireframe that contains lots of information not even pertinent to the view being drawn. Of course, you have to have internalized the proportions, planes, etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6512970
Even Loomis himself confuses things. See picrel from "Fun with a Pencil." The latitudinal line running around the ball is curved as if the ball is being seen slightly from above, but the longitudinal line is drawn as if we are at eye level with the center of the ball. If we were actually viewing the ball slightly from above, the "spit" running vertically through the ball would come down somewhat and be seen inside the outline, and the curve of the longitudinal line would be different.

posts.com:
My shitty day 1 paintings have sparked more joy and happiness in the world than anything I've made since I started grinding fundies and caring about being good.

People seriously underestimate the importance of having a more childish, carefree drawing phase. If you got into art late you missed out on this and this is unironically where taste an sovl develops. Instead, people will usually just start out grinding and end up becoming soulless boring retards that only get superficial praise from other artists. But can never create anything soulful or of note.

I'm not against learning fundamentals. It's just that there are pretty much zero notable artists who started with obsessive fundies grinding. They just drew what they liked all day long, learned what they needed, and so on. Versus you who paints cylinders and doomgrinds expressionless floating anime heads in-between shitposting and scrolling.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I draw daily and carry around a sketchbook. I draw "for myself" but tactically use my habit to garner attention and feedback from others. Showing the people close to me how much I improve means a lot to me, drawing people I meet is almost always rewarding even if I mess it up people don't care and are interestedin hearing the stories behind a few other drawings, even if it's commentary as simple as "here I was practicing feet" or "this is when me and some friends met and everyone contributed to the sketch!". It's an interesting story because it humanizes the illustrations and gives you motivation to a)improve and b)continue.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6510298
If we are talking about the skill itself of drawing, nepotism can help because someone can teach you how to draw.
But what you wanna sell, a lot of it is social media clout and/or connexions , irl or online.

The bigger the audience the more exposure you get , meaning more people will want to comission you, get enough people to consistently line up for comissions and now you can draw for a living. Pay is not 100% related to skill, sure skill/quality of the actual is an aspect but there are other things, take for example pic rel , how much do you think that should cost based on the quality of the artwork/skill of the artist, anyways this has been sold for 86,4 million dollars.
Let's not forget that comissions are much more "lottery" than a wage to my knowledge, with comissions you might get some rich guy that wants you to draw the most fucked up shit imaginable for a nice sum of cash worth a month's salary for like 4-6 hours of work, and then you might not see a comission for the next 3 months.
As far as I know the "game" goes as follows:
>Draw stuff and improve at drawing
>Post stuff on twitter and wherever tf your tentacles can reach
>Find artist clique of similar skill level and similar audiences
>Start interacting with eachother a lot so followers rub off one another. (maybe develop a legitimate friendship as well , which ever comes first, usually the first "self intrested" one I would say)
>Advertise commissions

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The general thread for Manga / manga-styled comic-making, manga-style illustration and related comic work.

Support each other and talk about your work or the work of others that excites you. Inking, character design, paneling / layout, writing, planning, and other discussions are all welcome.
Post resources, questions, in-progress pages, breakdowns of other works, etc. If a work is not yours, credit the maker (unless it's fucking obvious like a full page of One Piece or something).
Thanks to everyone for making /mmg/ a level-headed and helpful place. Remember, drawing and making comics and manga are difficult endeavors, and we're all in this struggle together.

Previous thread: >>6478292

/asg/, our stylistic sister-thread series for those focused more on illustration >>>/ic/asg

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Some western / indie publishers of Manga:

Saturday AM ( https://www.saturday-am.com/ )
> Digital indie magazine, seems to be on the up-and-up
> Open submissions for long-form series; also distributes series currently being published elsewhere.
> Regularly publishes one-shots, making it a good potential outlet for already-finished work.

Noir Caesar ( https://www.noircaesar.com/ )
> Focuses on black (specifically African-American) content, but seems willing to publish anyone good enough.
> Seemingly series-based only.
> No "magazine" style updates; series are updated on their own schedule.
> Seems less regular than Saturday AM, but also seems larger in terms of readership.

Oni Press ( https://onipress.com/ )
> Technically indie, but at this point large enough by comic standards to be mentioned in the same breath as other publishers.

Antarctic Press ( https://antarctic-press.myshopify.com/ )
> Longtime large-indie publisher of OEL / manga-esque books.
> Seemingly taking submissions at present if http://www.antarctic-press.com/html/submissions.php is anything to go on.

Yen Press ( https://yenpress.com/ )
> Started out as a small indie publisher of original / Korean material, and has grown reasonably popular since.
> As of 2016, it is also one of the western arms of the Kadokawa Corporation, with Kadokawa owning a 51% stake.
> Editorial inquiries can apparently be sent to yenpress@yenpress.com, however, they apparently are not open to new submissions at this time.

Viz Media / Viz Originals ( https://www.viz.com/originals )
> *The* western manga publisher.
> Currently in the exploratory stages of setting up an English label.
> Submissions are open and several books have been announced. However, progress on the label seems to be moving very slowly.
> Still might be worth a shot anyway.

Shrine Comics ( https://shrinecomics.com/ )
> Small indie manga publisher
> Seemingly attempting to make the transition to physical volumes
> Allows crossposting to other sites

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Other open comic publishers:

Dark Horse ( https://www.darkhorse.com )
>Dark Horse still welcomes your submissions, and all submissions will still be reviewed, just as they always have been.
>All unsolicited story/series proposals must have a full creative team on board. Writer-only proposals will not be reviewed.

Image comics ( https://imagecomics.com/ )
>Image Comics only publishes creator-owned material. They do not contract creators; they’re only interested in publishing original content for which you would retain all rights.
>Image Comics publishes creator-owned/creator-generated properties and THEY DON’T PAY PAGE RATES. Image takes a small flat fee off the books published, and it will be the responsibility of the creators to determine the division of the remaining pay between their creative team members.

Drawn and quarterly ( https://drawnandquarterly.com/ )
>Please email a low resolution PDF with at least 20 pages of comics and cover letter to submissions. Do not send dropbox links, scripts, or proposals. Please read our submissions FAQ.

Fantagraphics ( https://www.fantagraphics.com/ )
>submission page: https://www.fantagraphics.com/pages/faq

Top Shelf Productions ( https://www.topshelfcomix.com/ )
>Regarding submissions, we're easy. Just email us a download link of what you'd like us to review. NOTE: We cannot accept cover letters, plot synopses, or scripts unless they are accompanied by a minimum of 10-20 completed pages (i.e., fully inked and lettered comic book pages).

Additional publisher lists:

How are your profits? Do advertise your work outside of this place?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6497881
Hi anon. I mainly make profits from selling my books and original page art at art shows and comic and anime conventions. I fund my print runs with crowdfunding campaigns, and then sell the books for pure profit at shows. My evergreen bestseller is Purrvana, a colorful watercolor painted psychedelic cat graphic novel that appeals to normies of all ages and all demographics from bikers to gangsters to grannies to crazy cat ladies. I have sold over 2,500 copies of Purrvana to date. I also make money from commissions, both my OCs and other people. Most of my commissions are catfight wrestling matches featuring my OCs or other people's OCs. I advertise mainly on pixiv, discord, twitter and my webcomic also works as an advertisement. I also drew animal coloring books years ago that still sell, at shows and online. After a bad experience working with a publisher several years ago, I began self publishing and now that's all I want to do.

I read that Image creators are in the red and go in to debt with Image unless their book sells a certain amount of copies. I recently read tweets from an image artist who says that after his book he worked on sold 5 issues at 15,000 issues each, he only made $1100 in profit and he got paid months after the final issue came out, after the profit share was split with image, the writer and colorist. I don't sell a high volume of copies, and my crowdfunders don't go crazy, but I still make a lot more profit than that Image artist whose book was selling 15,000 copies each issue for example because I keep all the profit of sales for myself. I also do freelance work. Advertising and marketing is not really something I'm good at, but I'm getting by and trying to improve at it. I'm also going to start a life drawing class at my local Junior College next week and I hope it will up my skills so I can charge more for commissions, and it will also improve my comic pages. No rest for the wicked.

>But now Im starting feel the idea is over done and Im wondering if I should revise it.
As long you have a unique 'twitst' or take on the genre then you'll still stand out in an oversaturated market.
I'd even go as far as say it can be advantageous to use a popular genre/setting like isekai because your audience will immediatly know what to expect.
>"It's an isekai with cool battles, knights, monsters and magic? It's just like the other isekai's I love!"
You can essentially bait an audience and have fun with it by subverting isekai tropes and expectations.
>"that isekai by anon isn't like your average isekai! It looks generic at the beginning but slowly turns into this super deep subversion of the genre. It's fucking peak fiction!"

That's for example the kind of comments isekais like Mushoku Tensei, Re:Zero, Tanya the evil and Konosuba get.
>"It's an isekai but without the shitty writing and blatant power fantasy elements. I swear it's good!"

It's great that you're questioning your creative direction and want to find a unique and fresh angle for your comic. I recommend researching other cultures and periods of time for inspiration. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6506118
I write up a rough outline, then do dialogue, then do another pass and at least one rewrite before I start on chapter 2, then I keep going until the entire thing is written and I don't have a single page drawn because I'm eternally ngmi
Then I start it all over again with a new idea

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6506118
I write the dialogue right onto the page, using it as a sort of marker for where the panel's going to be (also using a brief non-dialogue description of the panel if there's no dialogue I think I might forget what's supposed to go there) for a few pages at a time, then I go back and quickly storyboard it. I do this in chunks of 2-5 pages at a time, not really coinciding with scenes or anything. This allows me to work out the pacing, phrasing and dialogue all at once.
