>>6509961
>Demon Slayer outsold the entire western comic industry by itself.

"It is important to contextualize where these numbers came from to begin with. Matrix cites Otaku USA, which in turn cites Anime News Network. The ANN article in question is about Demon Slayer's sales in Japan for the October 19-25 week in 2020, according to Oricon. Though not part of the headline story, the article states that the series had 100 million copies in circulation (including digital copies, which Oricon does not count), not sales, as of the 22nd volume's release on October 2.

Neither ANN nor Otaku USA reported on American comic book sales. The video version of Matrix's article indicates that his source for the "15 million" number is a sankaku Complex article, which in turn cites comic book blog The Beat's analysis of NPD BookScan data for 2019. It should be noted that the analysis is restricted only to the top 750 titles, so the 15 million figure applies only to that selection. It should also be noted that BookScan only represents a selection of retailers, and is not representative of the entire market.

That said, even the 15 million figure from The Beat's limited-scope analysis is a lower amount than Oricon's reported sales figures for Demon Slayer in 2019: 12 million copies. That figure is also disputed; publisher Shueisha reported that the manga sold 10.8 million volumes that year. So Demon Slayer clearly didn't outsell the American comics industry in the same frame of time. By conflating Demon Slayer's lifetime circulation numbers with yearly sales and stacking them against partial sales numbers in the American market for 2019, the numbers provided in Matrix's article paint a misleading picture."

And this source came from a anime focused website . YA and creator owned series do well in sales . The only real decline in sales is coming from marvel and dc(which is a good thing).

>>6502758
You don’t need to master anatomy or any other skill to do well in it. Stylizing is far more important for success. It needs to look good for people to want to spend money on it. Think about finishing some of your sketches. It’s more important to be able to create a finished, colored piece that can stand on its own. Clients don’t want sketches or perfect anatomy, they want pretty pictures. Just have solid fundies and start stylizing. Don’t get stuck striving for mastery, it’s a beg-trap.

No idea if this is just another AI bait thread or not, but I will be very honest to you: Don't bet solely on it. Have a plan B. I have witnessed first-hand when the Internet came along. I remember when Tim-Berners Lee was sitting in his chair on the '94 conference explaining what he just invented (the WWW as we know it). People were ignorant and incredibly dismissive of what WWW would bring to us. I have seen people, companies, etc. fail terribly due to their ignorance and inaccurate prediction. Please don't make the same mistakes.

What I'm trying to say, anon, is that you should do the best that you can, but to have an alternative plan at hand. AI will absolutely be the next big thing in this and the following decade. It will probably happen even faster than with the Internet. It will make the requirements for jobs much harder to met, jobs will be replaced, etc. Yes, I'm aware of the political, social and philosophical consequences and I can also understand the nihilist depression that recent trends of AI has caused. But the best you can do right now is to look forward. Do what you can do best, but prepare for the worst.

Well, you are right and wrong. Everything hits a ceiling, but with tech it is usually because people then have no idea how to improve it further. This is how ChatGPT competitor was trained, one that is slightly better but not released to the public. We already experienced one singularity with AI in one field that is very simple for AI, Chess. Chessbots first trained against humans, then trained against chess robots and then hit skill ceiling in the stratosphere. First they beat world champion grandmasters, then they battle against each other and now we have chess bots that are something like several billion times better then the best grandmasters. CGI is still made by humans and you can only get certain amount of realism from 3D models that have effects that humans can think of. Every AI workflow that's supposed to be convenient is long and boring. On the one hand, it's pushed me to do more with my art and give me ideas on to draw, like a writing prompt, and do more than just draw characters in a void. It also got me animating my work and not rushing to feed any algorithm just out of sheer spite.
On the other hand, trying to edit an AI picture feels like a stupid seek and find game. I don't feel satisfied. I don't want to post it anywhere. There is nothing fulfilling and fun about fixing basic shit like eyes or hands on something that would take me 60-120 mins to draw and render from scratch.

posts.com:
>>6515278
I made my research on character design with the anons in the OC redraw thread; if you want to nail your character designs, here's some guides it could help you.
>A good character design is easy to read even without a literal description of them or their lore
When designing, you have to be able to tell the basics of a character using their visual design alone, stuff like who they are, what they do, what they like, etc... if you can make the viewer understand the basic of your character without having to explain much to them, you are on a good track.
>A good character design stands out
When designing, think of those special visual traits that make your character not only different, but interesting as well, something like visual cues. Visual cues are important because they can be used to tell something about your character and make them stand out better.
>A good character design stays true to it's basics regardless of art skills
This is tricky, but if your design is good enough, your character should be able to maintain their essence even if it's drawn by a beg or a pro. If the character's basics are unconsciously overwitten when someone redraws them, then there's a few things missing.
>A good character design is engaging and fun
This is the most difficult, yet most rewarding part, your character needs to be able to not only hook the viewer, but also keep them engaged, it's that spark that makes them feel happy to see them or happy to draw them. This is difficult to achieve as it's quite subjective, but usually it helps to keep the design simple and true to all tips above.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The most important drawing skill is unaided observational sketching. I mean that as your ability to simply draw from observation in one fell swoop - no measuring, no proportion guidelines, no autistic angle comparisons, no excessive abstractions to see the subject as a series of nonsense shapes, no adjusting until it looks right. Just drawing rapidly with a high degree of accuracy.

This doesn't mean when making a portrait you shouldn't use all of those techniques, or that when drawing a meant-to-be-finished piece you shouldn't nitpick it as much as you please. I just mean that in terms of overall improvement potential, the person who has the ability to quickly observe and effortlessly sketch will be able to complete more, and better, studies in a shorter period of time than those who have to really put forth great effort to draw from observation. It carries over to efforts to drae from imagination as well - the man who can copy Bridgman with 80% accuracy by way of quickly executed sketches will complete the study in a few days with fewer barriers between his observation and understanding, while the guy who has to carefully plan, observe, and measure in order to reach maybe 60% accuracy might take many weeks, if he ever finishes at all, and at some point the intent becomes lost as he resorts to brute-force copying, the images he's observing becoming the observational equivalent of hearing a word repeated too many times - images without meaning. The first guy is left with a clearer, better memory of the whole of what he copied and can therefore better carry it over to his own work, while the second guy is left with a pile of drawings that were ultimately an effort of labored copying as opposed to actual learning.

>>6508772
I think the important thing that some people overlook is that studying fundamentals and working on raw observational work shouldn't be done to the exclusion of drawing from imagination and working on your personal projects. I saw somebody equating this to somebody who wants to run hyperfocusing on studying ideal gait mechanics and whatnot instead of just going out and running. Sure, you might be great at doing your studies and at some level know what you should be doing, but it takes time and effort to have your studies really stick and show through in your original work. Look at Proko, the guy can make some great stuff when engaged in careful observational work, but when it came to applying his knowledge through creative drawing and cartooning, he immediately struggled (though I think he's since worked on this). Regularly drawing what you want, especially from imagination, helps to keep your studies contextualized as feeding your knowledge base for your original work ("studying these female gymnast photos will help me draw my fit comic book heroine in stable, dynamic poses") as opposed to studies for the sake of studies ("yes, my copy of this image which happens to be a photo of a female gymnast is about 75% faithful to the reference; next time I will try to boost it to 80%").

>>6494195

ok anon I'm a beg (picrel a sketch from some 38 days ago and an attempt at a hard edge painting just so you can judge my advice based on my work) but if I may try and give some advice:
>Should I do them all probably right?
This feels like a kind of hyper-ambitious planning many people here, including me, are guilty of having done but realistically it usually doesn't work out and I think you will agree with me that it's a very big task and my advice would be to just choose one, see it through and then decide where to go next.
>8 hours at most isn't nearly enough time to explore something that takes like a year on DAB
I only went through the first few lessons of Peter Han's course, so again take my advice with a grain of salt, but the point isn't to master it all in 8 hours, the point is for him to give you the theoretical knowledge in each lecture and then for you to practice applying it by yourself afterwards before you move on and then throughout the whole course, going back to and refining concepts you've learned earlier.

My advice would be to choose one course that you feel drawn to, preferably one that's touted as good and by a good teacher, and then go at it fully. Don't just watch the lectures, find your own references and try drawing from imagination, too, practice is important.

In general, I think you should also do timed practice, here are some of the websites I've found nice, you can choose a timer and then you get automatically served different kinds of photos - there's people, hands, feet, heads, animals, plants and buildings
http://sketchdaily.net/
https://quickposes.com/en/gestures/timed

What has helped me the most was the start of Vilppu's Drawing Manual (I didn't get too far kek) and Hampton's Figure Drawing - learn to see curves and forms and to work with and draw gesture (use the 30 and 60 second timers on the above websites to practice this), a gesture is the building block on which you then plaster forms to create anatomy.

>>6511803
alright if DAB resonates with you then do that, from what I've seen of the course much of it focuses on construction and is quite technical in some aspects so I would recommend you do general gesture and non-construction sketching at the same time too

choose one of the sites I'd linked or a different one and do batches of 30 and 60 second drawings of humans, animals, bodyparts and whatever else they have here, you want to be able to quickly jot down the main lines of a "thing" instead of having to rely solely on detailed construction, especially when sketching (later you can do the construction to get everything looking absolutely right and correct after having your initial sketch done)

ofc go above 60 seconds, but 30 and 60 are good for learning to do stuff asap which forces you to learn to see and use only the main lines instead of getting lost in the details

and of course don't forget to keep drawing for fun, if it starts feeling like a slog to even get started drawing for the day then just draw whatever else comes to mind, having fun and staying engaged is the single most important part - the more you enjoy drawing, the more you will (ideally) draw and in the end that's what moves you forward, don't fall for the endless grind meme
best of luck anon!

>>6505842
The only thing Aesprite gives you that CSP doesn't is pixel perfect lines, which is a huge timesaver. You can get that on free alternatives like Libresprite and PixilArt.
I used to use CSP for pixel art, but the brush engine is too enthusiastic to lay points down, and there's next to no color management for controlling palettes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6509664
I should add that Aseprite has color and palette management, unlike CSP. Color and contrasts are what carry pixel art, so that's important.
That being said, unless you're looking to get away from CSP, you should look up the pixel tools in the assets store if you haven't done so already. They're fun to play with.

>>6509559
Dynamic Sketching is a good course, but it was first developed as a subject on Art Center's illustration and Entratainment Design programs.

The thing is that there Prefessors can assume that students will be having other fundamentals courses at the same time. When it got ported to the internet, through CGMA, there was also a program there that expected you to have a good basis on perspective before going to Dynamic Sketching. (Check CGMA's Foundation & Design Track)

If you don't have that basis especially in perspective, and you are a bit older and so don't blindly trust an instructor but rather "want things to make sense" you'll feel exactly as you've described: not prepared for next steps.

You need a basis before moving on. For that I would recomend:

-Beginner's Guide to Art Fundamentals - Forest Imel (ArtStation)
-The Art and Science of Drawing - Brent Eviston (Udemy)
-Absolute Beginners - Yves Yumol (CGMA)
-Art-WOD's Beginner's Course - Antonio Stappaerts (Art-WOD)
-The Art and Science of Figure Drawing - Brent Eviston (Udemy)
-Essentials of Realism - Jonathan Hardesty (Schoolism)
-Beginner’s Guide to Drawing - Steve Huston, Chris Legaspi, Heather Lenefsky, Bill Perkins, Joshua Jacobo, John Asaro, and Mark Westermoe (NMA.art)
-Ctrl+Paint Free Video Library - Matt Kohr (Ctrl_Paint)

posts.com:
To draw like this, you need to do these things...
Do gesture studies
Learn about shape language so that the composition and shapes are not monotonous
Copy the artists you like (don't do it mindlessly like a monkey. Ideally you should first analyse the whole piece, then do it yourself. If it looks wrong, compare it with original and see the mistakes. Don't do it again)
Learn basic perspective and form a little.
About colour, be subtle with it and learn the basics.
Theory is important but don't get stuck with it. Learn the basics and try to be creative with what you have. If you get stuck in theory, you'll try to know it all and there isn't end to all of this. And this, sometimes, can end your creative pursuit and you'll become just a great craftsman at most

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6508736
>Just because the japs did the inbetweens doesn't mean they had much or any effect on the actual character designs and art styles.
Japanese studios were full service studios. They did the inbetweens, keyframes, layout, animatics, sometimes even a 2nd pass over storyboards and character designs. It's actually quite rare to outsource only inbetweens, because inbetweeners need to be supervised by the keyframe artist and the director. They need to be under one roof. What's far more common, even today, is farming out entire shots to different animators/studios.
When it comes to outsourced cartoons of the 80s-2000s, basically everything you see on screen was drawn by the Japanese studio, minus the background occasionally. Pragmatically, the animation studio matters the most to the looks of a show. When people talk about the visual quality and designs of cartoons like Animaniacs, they don't talk about which director or which storyboarder worked on which episode. They talk about it in terms of the outsource studio.

>>6498614
I use a very tight 'precision' grip with my thumb,index and middle fingertips. I can only work on a single page or 2 a day maximum before it starts hurting.

The grip is so strong that when I put down the pencil there is a slight indentation on my fingertips from holding the pencil so hard. As expected, the paper gets pretty beat as a result.

I manage to mitigate this some by using a rubber grip or just putting a small piece of those kneaded rubber erasers around the area where I hold the pencil.

I honestly feel uncomfortable holding it in any other way.

>>6510951
Short answer: No

Becoming an int for me felt like falling asleep. When you wake up in the morning you can remember how you were laying on your bed, how you closed your eyes, and then bang and you remember how you woke up. I cant remember when exactly my art started to look decent, but it does now. I remember then i was only starting to draw and was thinking "damn, these artists are so good, but they never tell how exactly they became good, except saying something like "keep drawing". All people i know draw as bad as me, and they are real, but these people on internet who draw well, are they even real?"
Now i sometimes think, will i ever cross the line of being a generic int? But then i remember how i became int, and i keep on grinding

Good luck, bro, you'll get it

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
There’s nothing particularly off about his drawings but also nothing except Nazi iconography and runes, which is a repetitive geometric shape that he probably draw for comfort while there’s nothing to do. A few figures and environments but nothing that ambitious. Which I don’t fault him for per se, he is fighting for his life in between long bouts of anxious nothing.
Doesn’t seem to be the kind of guy to ask for art critique, but if he was I would probably say figure drawing, studying perspective for the sake of drawing classical architecture, or if he could afford to do so, learning to sculpt would take him in a good direction. As for maintaining sovl, I think for anyone that means drawing your own creations to completion and not just studying.
With ultra-begs I’ve found that giving them one thing to work on for awhile is good enough for the short term, so I’d probably tell him to work on perspective or figures, his choice.
Was never in the military, but I’d consider observing my environment, the people in it, the equipment I use, etc for inspirations and subjects to practice on. Because this nigga ain’t going to a life drawing session every Wednesday or going to the plain air meetup.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6514403
ctrl+paint is good for what you want, don't take it too linear go to a video that peak your interest if you feel there are gaps in knowledge just go back and so on.
Some tricks that may help you in lineart but aren't covered on ctrl
-play with round and square tip brushes, I like square/rectangular better for line art.
-for tricky lines that overlay you can create a tmp layer draw the line you want erase what you don't need and then merge both.
-there's a layer mode called eraser what ever you draw on it will be erased on layers below in a non destructive manner
-instead of using pen pressure from 0 to 100% play with narrower ranges like 60 to 100% its easier to control while keeping line weight.

Small tablets aren't best for drawing/painting if you can get a used one that is medium, there's no need for a screen one yet as you go on you will know the time to get one, before I got my screen one I just sketched on paper take a photo and keep working on it with a screenless tablet.

>>6514499
>but he inkerd them befor that to make it easier to get a clean lineart by playing with the levels
Inking before scanning is just to make it easier, but you can get great results with just normal a pencil. You need better lighting, try using an external source of light, it most be even and a little softer (a piece of paper is great to soften the light), the settings of the camera/app would be something like wb:fluorecent, iso 100 and ev around 0.7, take the photo parallel to the page to avoid any warping.

>any place were I can see a project in action to get a better grasp of them?
most of the things I mentioned are applied here

Why You Should Copy Anime:
https://i.imgur.com/zNDsyF0.jpg
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kbKqIJcIUCw
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dgjx6y6B_G8
Krenz Accuracy Imgs: https://files.catbox.moe/tklkj8.rar

**Strive for quantity AND quality.**

Anime Studying:
>Copy anime references exactly and draw them from memory. Use illustrations, screenshots, anime figures, 3D models, etc.
>Don’t copy recklessly. Use construction, color theory, and other fundamental concepts to rehearse a drawing process that you can later easily manipulate for original artwork.
>Post all of your anime studies. Post even when you’re told not to. Create an art community that actually draws and improves together instead of just talking about it.
>Number your attempts and link to your previous posts.

>>6508497
anime shijuku or アニメ私塾 (shijuku means private school)
https://twitter.com/animesijyuku

This one is also run by veteran animator Yasuo Muroi, he started his career in anime industry by joining Studio Ghibli in early 2000s, it was a bad moment because by the time he joined some of veteran Ghibli-trained animators had already left the studio, like Kenichi Konishi, Masashi Ando and Kenichi Yoshida. Konishi and Ando left Ghibli to work with director like Satoshi Kon, while Yoshida became attached to Eureka Seven.

Anyway, Yasuo Muroi stayed as in-betweener at Ghibli working on outsourced projects and then left as a freelancer. He did eventually climb the ranks as an animator to animation director, and then storyboarder and episode director. To be honest, he isn't a prolific animator, or a genius one like Masashi Ando. But he's a hard worker and his lessons are suited for people like him who started from zero.

>would it really work out for foreigners
Man, the way anime industry works nowadays, they will accept anyone who can draw. Seriously.

These are my advice if you want to get into anime industry:
>Go watch Shirobako
>Grab The Animator's Survival Kit
it's intended for western animation, but you'll learn a lot by understanding the principles of animation.
>Watch these youtube channels
- Dong Chang
- Tonari Animation (a lot of know-how, anime 101 like what are storyboards, timesheets, how do you draw layouts, how to do cleanup, inbetween etc)
- Studio Bulldog
- YenBM
- World Anime Networks
- Desuran/ですらん (Keisuke Kojima)
- アニメ私塾 (Yasuo Muroi)
- hide channel【顔と体の描き方講座】for composition, pose, anatomy, fundamentals of drawing which is necessary for animation

Look up for keywords like: 作画タイムシート
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8-aPPX_rJZM
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KBEvDfjeLF4
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UBsvTdxwM6Q

>You also need to read many books on perspective, do croquis, etc.

>Most importantly get friends who have same interest in animation. Join sakugafoundry/Tonari Animation discord. This is a group of foreign artists and anime fans who learned animation from zero, they build community around anime production, some of their members are already assisting anime production as animators/cleanup artists/inbetweeners.

>Go make a twitter account and follow a lot of japanese animators and production assistants

>>6499169
id just download Peter Han Dynamic Sketching to supplement/replace Step 1, or even Bert Dodson Keys to Drawing as Step 0
i never did Stonehouse, but it might be a bit too intensive for this stage instead of Loomis, Hampton or Bridgman
do lots of drawing ideally from life but photograph is OK, geometric shapes, fruits, bottles, plants, birds, etc. then humans
never did vilppu, idk how good he is. personally id replace this with Marco Bucci 10 Minutes Series, Gurney Color + Light, Richard Schmid Alla Prima
*obviously final step is personal preference for what you want, but a lot of "how to draw anime" books/yt vids are really bad,
anime settei can be bad too for diff reasons (made for TV production so that animators can do the thousands of frames / episode quickly), use it for reference on how to draw a character more than your benchmark style. obviously this varies depending on how good the show production and char designers are
yoh yoshinari artbooks are crack though, download as many of those are you can

>>6513004
A lot of it is just carry over from the limitations of traditional mediums. If you do a bit of lining with pens you'll get a feel for whats comfortable and it just feels better to end lines like this then to try and make complicated sharp curves with a pen.
They aren't actively deciding to end the lines to make the best line art they are just conditioned to do it this way. You can use it as a technique to show form and light, look up lost edges.

>>6514096
I would be careful just repeating stuff mindlessly what art historians claim. Keep in mind they don't draw and get educated in an environment devoid of any classically trained artists. Note how there is no dialog between art historians and modern masters of painting and master draftsmen, it is to a huge part due to ego and disdain towards "craftsmen". The camera obscura theory claims that the main problem is a problem of accuracy or the drawing, which is not true. It is a big problem to most of us, but there is a compositional challenge, how to arrange stuff, choosing the perspective. I am baffled how educated people just sum the process up to "camera obscura" and just leave it there, like a mystery is solved in one word. Look at the figures, think about the actual challenge of painting in a camera obscura opposed to having drawing skills. Take a look at how masterfully he painted the horses in a few strokes and think again if a "drawing aid" would be helpful or an actual hinderance.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6514122
I think they are artificially constructed from careful sketches on location. I assume that after sketching for many weeks he would decide for a composition and then plot out a perspective grid on the final piece and place the buildings in this high up perspective. Like you would recreate a City in a 3D program, but in this case it's a fixed perspective. I am not sure of the accuracy of the paintings, even though I was in Dresden several times, but I would lean towards agreeing and say they are somewhat inaccurate but it makes the whole scene more grand and he fits more stuff in than would be able to see.

This is all my personal speculation though, it would need a more careful analysis for someone actually to really check it from the exact same viewpoints. The fact that all the viewpoints are high up makes it difficult to check if you were just walking around there like me.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
From what I remember, the two main characters were good case studies on two different kinds of creatives (in their formative years). The hikki kid was really talented and displayed strong technique early on, but their work tended toward life drawings and environments - pictures without people in them. On the other hand, Fuji's stand-in, while not as skilled, displayed a strong affinity and aptitude for crafting narratives; they were always looking for some way to tell a story through drawings.

Their reasons for taking up drawing are also believable, and, to a certain extent, relatable. The hikki girl draws all day every day because it's a viable form of escapism and there's not much else to do; Fuji's stand-in (I think, can't remember) does so partly because of the praise it earns her from peers.

In terms of which character /ic/ embodies best, I think the board leans slightly toward the former due to the lingering influence of the concept art era. It should be noted that quite a few people here see art as a means by which to secure a livelihood, usually through the patronage of a dedicated fanbase; this entails a focus on producing art that is very accessible, usually pin-ups and the like. I won't go so far as to say that an (erotically charged) illustration of a character against a simple background is entirely lacking in narrative, but a emotional response is certainly the foremost prerogative, whether it be in the form of a libidinal response or an appeal to the viewer's particular tastes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Let’s be honest, Bob Ross never painted anything that merited description beyond “trees in front of a mountain with water in the foreground”.
His paintings are (arguably by necessity of their intended purpose) extremely formulaic, low effort and devoid of thought, sentiment or value and painted entirely with “this quick easy trick makes artists mad click here to find out more” type nonsense like putting light and dark values on either side of the brush and just daubing to get random rocks with inconsistent lighting instead of teaching you to paint a fucking rock. Not once does he even reflect on the actual craft, he uses painting as therapeutic technique that utterly devalues the effort.
He’s like Kinkade if Kinkade had to make his paintings replicable by actual retards in 20 minutes.
Setting aside his therapeutic endeavours, altruism and nostalgia, he never contributed anything whatsoever to art, and that narrow context might as well have been painting prolapsed Chun Li assholes all day.

>>6505881
Not really, the pressure, deadlines, and above all the sovllessness of concept art is pretty rough. Coom art at least gives you complete flexibility with what you want to do. Want to focus on lineart? Want to paint super detailed? Want to do loose sketches? There's just a freedom and flexibility to it. You can also just work at your own pace and not have to work yourself into an early grave, there's no production pipeline that requires tight deadlines, the picture is the end result. It's the lesser of two evils for sure.

If you play your cards right, and find the right niche and clientele you'll actually have time in the week to work on your personal artwork, the stuff your original dreams were made of. Very little chance to do that when you're working 80 hours working on AAA normieslop.

>>6507208
The Bob Ross method is a series of parlor tricks, exactly like those videos of spray paint artists who make alien moonscapes using pot lids and crinkled newspaper. It has little to do with drawing or painting in a meaningful sense. Painting Bob Ross style is like filling out a coloring book, which can be fun and therapeutic I suppose, they do market adult coloring books as a de-stressor, but like that other anon said it has little to do with the craft of draftsmanship, painting or illustration.

>>6506067
Eventually you will have to put the things that exist within your soul on paper or they'll start eating you alive, and you'll grow out of love with drawing. It isn't easy to find time for them, and like you said people aren't likely to care. But you just have to do it, trust me on this.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I'm a professional animator at a North American studio, with a specialty in 2D frame-by-frame animation. I've been making my own short films since I was a teenager & I pirated a copy of Flash, uploading my work to Newgrounds & YouTube.

I've never made a dime off of any of my personal work, and I don't really have any fans or large following to speak of (my most popular videos only have about 5,000 views). But still I've kept at it, and plan to continue making animated shorts for the rest of my life, as it's something I'm truly passionate about.

I'm making all of these things in my free time while I continue to work my 9-5 job, and so I feel the budget for all of my stuff is basically $0.

However, I've seen lots of crap on Kickstarter & Indiegogo receive thousands, or even tens of thousands of dollars in funding. So it's got me thinking, how much could I conceivably ask for if I were to make a Kickstarter for the animated short that I'm currently working on?

Whether I receive any funding or not, the film will be finished eventually, probably in about 8 months time (I've already been working on it for a year). Like I said, I've made all of my stuff thus far for free, and so I don't technically need any funding.

But, if I can make $10,000 or so from Kickstarter just from making something that I'd already be doing anyway, that'd be pretty nice.

I won't reveal my identity or anything, but I'll say that the quality of the work I produce (based on my animation & compositing expertise) is about on par with the old Hellbenders episodes, so basically TV quality.

https://youtu.be/C1icpvvCxjo

>I'm thinking of getting the Wacom One, should I buy it?
Fuck off retard. Ask a better question.

Recommended tablets:

>Intuos 3
Best screenless tablet. Look for one on Craigslist or Ebay.
>Intuos 4, 5 & Pro
Also good options. Will burn through your nibs.
>Samsung Galaxy Tab S6 Lite
Budget portable display tablet. Very solid drawing experience with Wacom EMR tech, but a small 10.4" display area.
>Used iPad Pro 2nd Gen 12.9"
Best option for a display tablet.
>Galaxy Tab S7+/S8+
Good premium alternative to an iPad Pro
>One by Wacom (not Wacom One)
Solid cheap option

Avoid:

>XP-Pen, Huion, Gaomon and every other Chinese brand
Poor build quality, lackluster pens, broken tilt, struggles to register light pressure, horrible customer support and the displays are not calibrated. All Chinese brands have the same problems. Check out the webm to understand how bad they are. Also watch out, Chinese companies shill HARD on /ic/; they do a lot of samefagging and frequently hurl personal insults.

>Microsoft Surface Pro
The N-Trig digitizer means you will always get wobbly lines.

>Lenovo
Bad drawing performance because they're not designed with art in mind.

>iPads (brand new) - Bad value
>iMacs and Macbooks - Never buy this garbage under any circumstance. It's a locked ecosystem with rubbish hardware you can't upgrade.

I have an Artisul D16 (not pro) that I bought for about 300 of my local pesos a few years ago that I only just started using properly a few months ago when I started learning digital painting very seriously. It's a 15.6 inch screen drawing tablet.
I have been very fortunate that it doesn't seem to have any hardware issues (some scary reviews out there lmao) so far, but holy sweet mother does its software suck.
Coming from an ancient wacoom bamboo from like 2012 I just cannot believe how bad the software is. In general I am extremely grateful that the tablet was so cheap because I was that guy who thought that a screen less one would be just as good but let me tell you now that I've seen the light I can never go back.
The problem is that the D16's drivers are being held together with duct tape and cum and it just barely works even having lots of strange issues like I can't use the two side buttons on the pen because pressing one even for a second will remap the stylus to half way between my main monitor and the d16 display which I sometimes can't even fix upon several restarts of the computer. Loads of little headaches and setting it up for left handed use was hell.

Basically I never want another Chinese tablet again. I'm still running windows 10 and the driver to this tablet hasn't been updated since 2018 so I am mentally preparing myself for this tablet to just stop working when I'm forced to upgrade to win11 probly within the next year.
I dont use pen tilt and I've found that 15.6 inches I about all the space I have on my tiny desk and so far I haven't found that I wished the tablet was bigger (only that it worked better).
I have no idea about any of this tech stuff but all I want is a functional tablet with good software and support. I dont use pen tilt or even need buttons on the tablet (I have a keyboard). Because if this I'm heavily leaning to a less feature packed Wacom. I really don't want to buy used. Any ideas?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I actually got curious about the origins of pen tablets and I found many interesting things.

Of course, Wacom is Wacom, founded in Japan and still the top in quality.

Huion is an independent company from Shenzhen China, which you might notice, a lot of drawing tablets come from Shenzhen, this is not surprising as the place is actually known for tech export.
Anyway, it doesn't seem to be owned by some parent company or belong to a group, which is actually rare for China to be owned still as closely as a private company as it can with a single definitive CEO.

You have then the Havon Ugee group, also from Shenzhen.
They own: XP-Pen, Xencelabs and Ugee, which doesn't mean they're the same, I'm sure they have different R&D groups (I'd like to believe Ugee has one), but it means they can cooperate if mandated by the group, probably to share some info or tech or something.
You would think Ugee is their main selling company but no, it's XP-PEN, probably because unlike the other two XP-PEN is actually a Japanese-Taiwanese company that got bought, so it had a better start in the race and I'm sure is doing the heavy lifting on the group, both as r&d and in sales.
This sharing of tech would also explain Ugee's unconventional good quality, for a price range so cheap you would expect them to break apart in contact, but that's headcanon.
Xencelabs is their "premium brand", they appeared as a "Wacom killer" with some neat toys and elegant designs, but I don't know anyone who actually uses a Xencelabs over an XP-Pen, because even if they were better quality than an XP-PEN, and I doubt they reach newer Huion's, they do reach those Wacom prices.

Gaomon is from Guangzhou
Parblo is from Shenzhen
Veikk from Beijing
Not a lot of info on them, but neither seems to be owned by a group.

I've used:
Intuos 3
Intuos 4
Bamboo fun
Surface pro 3
Ipad 3 (before the apple pencil was a thing)
Ipad pro 1st gen
Ipad pro 3rd gen
Cintiq 24hd (the one from like 10 years ago)
Xp pen 24
Kamvas 22 plus
Kamvas 24 plus

The kamvas 24 is my favorite I've used. But ended up opting for a 22 instead to save like $300 or something, because the drawing experience was only very marginally worse (and takes up a little less desk space)

The etched glass is a very nice surface to draw on, and there are no accuracies issues except in maybe the last 1/4" that you won't be drawing in anyway.

My iPads I've always used an elecom screen protector, and it's very good, but the grit wears down after not that long, and it's a bit waxy feeling (very similar feeling to the xp pen screen protector)

posts.com:
I've been using huions for a few years now and I can say my only real problem with them has been that on the micro-USB corded tablets, the connection ports wear out. By this point I prefer a screenless tablet, but I was getting very frustrated with my 1060 disconnecting over and over because the plug was wearing out.

A few weeks ago I decided I'd try one of their wireless tablets, and found an odd one that appealed to me, the KD200. I was pleasantly surprised that they had changed the charging ports to USB-C, despite the website saying it was still micro-USB. It takes about an hour to charge it to full, which for an 18-hour battery life is very nice.

It wasn't advertised but since I'm a bit of a stop-and-start artist I liked that after about 5~ minutes it goes to sleep and stops wasting battery. I was able to get it for a good discount, 115 dollars instead of the 150~ i was planning to spend, and i'm pretty happy with it so far

>>6511209
It is a complicated situation. The cover on the left is straightforward and shows the most important elements of the game, but fails to convey the style of the game, which could lead someone to buy it expecting an action/adventure game. The cover on the right is more enigmatic and does a good job of describing the game, but it may only appeal to those interested in more experimental games (a rather small niche at the time).
The ideal would be to find a middle ground, a visually appealing cover that describes the game but does not scare away the more casual gamers. On the other hand, which is better, attracting the most people or focusing on an audience that is likely to appreciate the game? I mean, I've met several people who hate "art games" but love Ico and Shadow of the Colossus.

Your unconscious feminine tendencies - intuitively associated with your creativity, feelings, and among many other things, relating to others - remain undifferentiated from the mother imago due to your inability to relate to women. Pornography stunts this underdeveloped inner figure into something even more childlike and infantile, and this way of communicating with your unconscious mainly remains as a primitive sexual outlet.

This psychic factor, or "anima", has played a role in the psychology of men since the dawn of history, expressed in the imagery of muses, faeries, succubi, etc. If you do not develop and consciously integrate this femininity, it instead possesses you, and you paradoxically become even less masculine. If it's redirected entirely inwardly through waifu imagery, you grant it autonomy and it unconsciously possesses you even further. It drains more of your mental, sexual and creative energy than it replenishes, thus becoming vampiric and succubine. This is the dark, devouring, chthonic aspect of the feminine, and it is dangerously seductive.

This inner femme inspiratrice or soul-image can only fully come to life and be made conscious when it's projected onto a woman, and when that projection is later withdrawn and realized as an inner power. When such projection takes the form of deep infatuation, you instantly feel you've somehow known that woman your whole life, only to later realize that part of what you admire in her and can relate to is something you carry within.

The Oedipal myth is very complicated, despite what the Freudians say. When the Sphinx confronts Oedipus, she merely pretends to die when her riddle is cleverly answered, and this only perpetuates the tragic ending. Similarly, you cannot overcome this through the masculine powers of the mind - vacuous, avoidant intellectual pursuits - as it requires both creative inner realization and active relating to the outer world, especially to women.

In Jung's view, a man's mind has unconscious "feminine" aspects (vice versa with "masculine" traits of women). In men, they're often expressed in images and fantasies which are divine, nurturing, pornographic, etc. Their initial form is influenced by the man's mother and how he feels about her, which also influences his romantic attachments later in life.

In addition to the personal mother, there's an underlying "blueprint" within all men's minds of what a mother should be, what a lover should be, etc. This is archetypally responsible for the repeating motifs in myths, narratives, and in male psychology whenever "the feminine" is concerned.

If the different aspects of this inner femininity are not developed and differentiated, a man will be, among other things: unable to relate to others (especially women), feel insufficiently creative, be effeminately bitchy and moody, be unable to mentally separate himself from his mother, retreat into pornography, be attracted to women that are either far too young or too old, etc.

Obviously, relying on a single theory (e.g. Jung's) or diagnosis is limiting when it comes to anyone's unique situation. Ideally, one would approach it both from the outside-in (habits, measurable neurology, medication) or from inside-out (introspection, creativity, dream interpretation, spirituality - if one is inclined to those).

The problem with the Jungian approach isn't that it's strictly unscientific - it's deeply researched, has interdisciplinary precedent, and can be measurably helpful for people whom it intuitively clicks with. But it blurs into things that aren't measurable (thus falsifiable), and it's absolutely not something anyone can undertake, enjoy, or understand. I summarized some of it here because it might offer some context beyond seemingly wanting to fuck your own mother.

It's great that you feel you can relate to women in real life - I can't speak for your circumstances, I attempted to instead condense a lot of general tendencies that are often intuitive/relatable. And I think I could hardly offer any direct advice or prescriptions on here, given the problems you mentioned, and since I myself have serious SzPD traits.

Regarding denial/suppression and differentiation - I think whatever someone has as potential but doesn't live out, tends to then grow against them. Do you feel that deep down that you might still desire, or be able to pursue a romantic relationship? I think that mighty help you differentiate truly undiscovered aspects of yourself, unless you've really made peace with it. It also depends on finding someone you can actually fall in love with, which can be agonizing.

I'm not implying you should needlessly absolve people - I'm truly sorry that's happened to you, it's an absolute achievement to move on to the extent you have. But if you feel ready to approach whatever might be unresolved from your childhood, I'd recommend looking for a therapeutic approach that works for you. And keep making art <3

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6514437
>the human species and society are still evolving and have the potential to evolve
Sure, the question is over what timespan - much of the ways we function in modern society clearly doesn't jive with some earlier layers of our brains, and we don't know to what extent we could (or should) get used to it.

And obviously, most populations have changed since the last ice age - lactose tolerance, varying nutritional sources, new phenotypes, admixture with archaic human species, etc. Much of this clearly wasn't trivial.

But I don't think you can throw the baby out with the bathwater when it comes to looking for precedent in other species - sometimes this concerns mechanisms (like neurotransmitters) which function near-identically. But obviously, we can't draw direct animal parallels when it concerns our most unique features - such as society and language.

But I think remaining hunter-gatherer societies are best place to observe our most "natural" state, many aspects of which may even be considered "optimal" for mental and physical well-being, such as a population of around 150 people (Dunbar's number). Then again, what about the fact that most hunter-gatherer societies were/are matrilineal (not the same as matriarchal)? Is that optimal just for them or for everyone, and why? It gets weird and fuzzy since we're also incredibly adaptable.

>I hope you're not sexist enough to think women can't also be eccentric and defy "evolutionary incentives"
No, we're obviously carrying an organ which can override its' own programming in indescribably sophisticated ways, and it's had countless bizarre opportunities to do so as consciousness emerged over hundreds of thousands of years. So those bizarre circumstances have in turn uniquely shaped us. But while we're not deterministic animals, we still have to give the powerful underlying machinery its' due - that's not as simple as finding a precedent in something like biomechanics, but it's not all posthoc justification either.

>>6500787
I'd say focus less on the color, and learn to make a convincing solid drawing without it. Seems like you want to hurry up and get to the end result already, when really majority of your focus should be on the start of the drawing.
Let's say it takes 5 steps to complete a drawing. You want to make sure majority of your focus is on step 1 and 2, and the rest onto the others. Otherwise, there is some symbol drawing going on here. You'll need knowledge how How the body works, and not just relying on references.

So here's what I'd like you to do. Look for the book called "Morpho: Simplified Forms: Anatomy for Artists", it's a very easy book to find. Copy every drawing but Skip the heads. Only attempt to copy each drawing once. Judge it, if you feel the copy is off, learn from it, continue onto the next drawing.
Once you finish fully copying the book, do it again but from imagination. The imagination being; see the drawing, close the "book", try to draw what you recall. And go from there. Half your drawing time should be on completing this task, and the other half should be working on your personal stuff. You NEED to do both. As you do this, you'll start to make a connection between the importance of your studies and your own work. You'll be frustrated, you'll feel it's pointless, you'll even question why you're even doing this. This is normal, everyone goes through these emotions. Eventually, you'll start telling yourself "stupid fucking anon from fag making me do his exercise. So goddamn pointless I hate him. I HATE EVERYONE!!" but once you're done with the book, I guaranteed you, you will be at the level you were trying to aim for this entire time. And upon the 2nd copy, you'll truly ascend. You need the knowledge, without it you cannot get better.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6505644
gesture is always a hard thing to parse, and probably requires hundreds of hours of gesture drawing to really "get it" but I like the way Steve Huston describes it in his book "figure drawing for artists making every mark count" he's also done figure drawing courses on new masters academy and other places I think but the same info is in the book.
Gesture is just the relationship between parts with which you can lay their structure and form on top of, a cup on a table has a gesture because it has a relationship to (a relative position and movement away from) the table. Everything has gesture. I wish I could help more because it's been something I remember having trouble with.
But yeah you've got the gist from what I can tell, the energy, the movement, the relationship of the parts with which you can place the structure/ anatomy/ volume of the thing on top.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6513078
Twitter has the largest potential audience by far, but you're entirely at the whim of the dreaded Algorithm, and whether you get seen or noticed is, as far as I'm concerned, entirely random. If you want better chances, you'll need to be extremely consistent with your uploads.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6513109
So a routine of posting around the same time, amount of pics per week, etc?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6513161
That's what I hear. I have no solid numbers, and it's mostly conjecture anyways, but a few pics a week is probably a good place to start. Of course, your work has to be of a quality that naturally attracts some attention too. But even then that's not the rule, as I've seen some terrible artists with huge followings. Not sure how many of those are bots though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6513190
>Quality that naturally attracts
Considering your following sentence, Is there a standard or some element that draws people, or is it just personal taste? I can post some art, but my coloring/ shading is abysmal.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6513214
Of course personal taste plays a big part, and you can ignore most of what I'm saying if you cater to a specific fetish or fandom. But, and again this is just personal observation speaking, fully-rendered art tends to get more attention. Not to say sketches and linework don't, but they have to be pretty good to offset the lack of flashiness that non-rendered work has by virtue of simply having color and polish. The people who just scroll and consume artwork tend to be less interested in the minutiae of a drawing and more on how quickly it dazzles them. I've heard the figure being around three seconds to grab someone's attention; if it takes any longer, they've already scrolled past.

>>6493174
The statement that "pornography is the highest form of pure visual art" is incorrect and oversimplifies the role and purpose of art. Art is a form of human expression that has the power to evoke a wide range of emotions, spark creativity, and provide insight into the human experience.

Art also has the ability to uplift, inspire, and foster empathy. Through art, we can explore the beauty of life, the complexities of the human condition, and the majesty of the natural world. Art has the power to bring people together and create a sense of shared experience and understanding.

In contrast, pornography is often created for the sole purpose of sexual gratification and is focused on objectifying and exploiting people. It can damage the soul and harm society by promoting unhealthy attitudes and behaviors towards sex and relationships.

Art has the power to do so much more than just evoke a single emotion, it has the ability to challenge, educate, and transform the world. Therefore, to say that pornography is the highest form of pure visual art is a narrow and misguided perspective that fails to fully appreciate the depth and breadth of what art can accomplish.

Maybe because DM is one of the mascots of the franchise that existed since S1?

The most iconic cards are not judged based on artstyle but based on their relevance to the plot, how useful they are, and how much trolling you can do with them

For example: Summoned Skull has already disappeared from the plot but because he was the first otk card, no one can forget about him.

Time Magician appeared like 5 times only and at insignificant battles at that. But because he is an absolute troll of a card, he is also super iconic.
Then there's the Ojama cards that can turn any game into a fest of hilarity. One could argue that they became even more popular than winged Kuriboh despite having less exposure and weilded only by a secondary MC

The reason why the latest cards aren't iconic is simply that they lack these 3 reasons.
The plot don't like them
If they are powerful now, the next batch of cards would nerf them
And most of all: the effects are too damn complex for simple trolling

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Three reasons:

- Too much competition. Skilled artists are a dime a dozen, and that's what companies look for, so the soulful people who are not technically skilled get fucked in the ass;

- Back then, it was the artist at the inception, as one of the leading features of the franchise. Now the artist is just a rendermonkey working for a streamlined process ran by businessmen who have everything down to a formula;

- Imagery overload. Pictures are not precious anymore. Before the Internet, being able to see many different pictures every day was expensive, required a lot of effort. Collectibles were a nice way to keep a copy of that picture you saw on TV, you couldn't just google for it at any time, for free. So the meta was making something appealing that people want to collect. The meta now is making something that impresses people and stands out (by technical prowess) from the other, simpler options. Ironically, they end up arr rooking same, but tell that to companies, not /ic/.

Pic related is an amazing example of how the art field has evolved, a "beg" like this would never get a job these days.

Yeah, the cats blend into her arms. Overall, though, there are just two many areas of similar brightness and darkness, of similar size, so the pillows and sheets and a streak of light in the curtains are given as much importance as the girl and cats (more than, actually). There's no visual hierarchy. It's rendering without design. Even in a good newspaper ad containing only text, you see a hierarchy -- the headline will be huge to grab your attention, then maybe a subhead, then body copy which can be smaller because you're going to read it if the aforementioned caught your interest; a call to action at the bottom in bold text provides balance, while the disclaimers are almost illegibly small. When everything is important, nothing is important.
